description:
Hibernian Social Club of Brussels


The Irish in Europe Association launched the Hibernian Social Club at the Aloft Brussels Schuman Hotel, December 6th.in 2011.

We resume our meetings on Friday first of February at 18.00 at the Aloft Brussels Schuman Hotel.

The aim of the Social club is to help promote micro integration, networking and business in Brussels. It also promotes Belgian-Irish and Inter-State Trade in Europe and of course to have a good time over a beer or a Cocktail in a Social Club ambiance at the WXYZ Bar on the ground floor. Naturally it also serves a hub to share information on the latest developments in the EU and the progress being made on the Irish Presidency of the Council of Ministers.


Admission Free,everyone is welcome!!! But please sign the Guest Book and bring your business cards.


Come early and avail of the split Happy Hour starting at 6 to 6.30pm!!!!

Split Happy Hour 2 for 1! Every day at the Aloft from 6 to 6.30 pm and from 8 to 8.30pm
Mix, meet and mingle over cocktails, light bites or a game of pool. Happy Hour 2 for 1 includes only: draught beer, house wines, soft drinks, cocktail of the week (2nd drink is a shot)

Coming Directly after Work? You can have cold bites small hot bites, and big hot bites including pasta meals, sandwiches, deserts and pizza…..


All nationalities that have an interest in Ireland and working with the Irish Diaspora in Europe and around the world to develop commercial,trade,social and cultural links are most welcome to attend.
We will also discuss the up coming Brussels Saint Patrick’s Day Parade of the Nations and Regions, and the up coming Irish in Europe Cultural Programme in the coming Months including the Irish in Europe Art and Photo Exhibition and our cultural fusion program for the months of March and April “Crossing Borders in the Internal Market” where the Irish meet a specific nationality. We need country co-coordinators to help with this Meetup program.


The Parade is a multicultural opportunity to bring families and community organisations together at one big event, to get to know new comers and to make new friends and bridge the cultural divide with other communities. Please come along and let us know how you would like to contribute or share your ideas, and or if you would like to join our committees to help to organise the fifth Parade, cultural and micro integration events-let us know. [masked]


If you are traveling to Ireland via Cork or Dublin airport, we will be delighted to provide you with some travel tips. If you are seeking work in Ireland, at the present there are hundreds of multilingual vacancies in Ireland in certain skill areas. Let us know your job interests.

Irish in Europe Association (International) AISBL (Incorporating the Brussels Saint Patrick’s Day Parade of the Nations & Regions Committee).


Membership is open to all nationalities.

description:
You are cordially invited to our after work event with an Irish Harp Recital with a pre view of the Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition. The Harp Recital is by Formiga and Cigale www.formigaandcigale.com. Their repertoire is from all Europe: France, Catalonia, Scotland, Ireland, Russia, and Belgium. The Irish repertoire includes : Women of Ireland, Paddy s green shamrock shore, Danny boy, Raglan road, Irish rover, Fields of Athenry, Fig for a kiss, Foggy dew, O' Carolan tunes, and  different Jigs, reels, ballades, Val's and polkas.

We are having an opening preview of the Irish in Europe Art and Photo Exhibition from 5pm to 7pm on Thursday 7 March with the Irish Harp music recital.  The Official opening of the 'Like the Tree' Exhibition takes place afterwards from 7pm on the same evening. Guests have the option of remaining on in the entertainment/restaurant/bar area where they will be able to purchase a meal or refreshments.

The Irish in Europe Association (International) AISBL are organising the 50 day Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition “Cork meets Brussels”- “Brussels meets Westport”-“Bringing Brussels and Ireland closer together in Europe”  in Brussels in association with The Gallery Kinsale at Halles Saint Gery Cultural Centre, 1 Place Saint Géry, 1000 Brussels (Metro Debrouckere).

The Exhibition opens on March 7 and lasts until April 28. It is expected that at least 20,000 people will visit the exhibition and about 10 million people will read about it. The main objective of this exhibition is to promote relations between Brussels and Ireland and Ireland as a holiday destination and in particular promote its 2013 partner promotion regions Cork City and County and Westport and Mayo County. In addition to distributing the all Island Tourism Ireland information guide, there will be special Cork and Mayo County information stands. These stands will be manned by volunteers for 7 days a week during the exhibition.

The Exhibition will be officially open every day from 10am to 6pm to the public. Admission is free. We will be having other Irish cultural and micro integration events such as ‘Crossing Borders in the Internal Market’ and receptions over the 50 day period.

If you have a group that wishes to organise a social evening or  outing to Halles Saint Gery, let us know and we will arrange a private showing of the exhibition for your friends, work colleagues or your guests after the normal exhibition closing time.

Be present for the launch of new works of art and see them for the first time!!!

Jacques Brel meets Rory Gallagher....this painting is going to be a big talking point in the music world.

Looking forward to meeting you at the preview if not then over the next 50 days at the Exhibition.

Denis J. Buckley

Irish in Europe Association

If you like with the planning and organising of  Irish in Europe Meetup events including the Brussels Saint Patrick’s Day Parade of the Nations and Regions, Irish in Europe Art and Photo Exhibition and related cultural, social and micro integration events in March and April at the Saint Gery Cultural Centre, please come along to a planning meeting at Halles Saint Gery at 12 Noon on Saturday 9 March . We would also like to hear from people who can help with some translation from English into French, Dutch and German. We meet up stairs at the Irish in Europe Exhibtion.All nationalities are welcome.

description:
This annual lecture will be given in French for the first time,let all your French speaking friends know!!

Admission free. Everyone welcome .

FR:  Cette conférence (en français) traitera de l’histoire de la langue irlandaise (gaélique), quelques liens des irlandophones avec la Belgique, la situation de la langue à présent, et proposera des idées pour améliorer l’apprentissage des langues en général.

GA:  Pléifear sa chaint seo (as Fraincis( le stair na Gaeilge, le cuid de na naisc idir lucht labhartha na Gaeilge agus an Bheilg, agus molfar roinnt smaointe chun foghlaim teangacha i gcoitinne a fheabhsú.

EN:  This talk (in French) will discuss the history of the Irish language, of some links of Irish speakers with Belgium, and will propose some ideas for the improvement of language-learning in general.

description:
CINÉ-CONCERT: Irish Destiny
Royal Chamber Orchestra of Wallonia
George Dewhurst

 

Saint-Patrick’s Day, Irish Presidency of the European Union, Irish Film Institute.

The first full length feature film made in Ireland, Irish Destiny is a passionate love story set against Ireland’s War of Independence. Now restored to its original hand tinted and toned glory, Irish Destiny is brought to life by live orchestral performance of the sumptuous score by Mícheál Ó Súilleabháin commissioned by the Irish Film Institute.
Flagey, Culture Ireland, Royal Chamber Orchestra of Wallonia, Angloinfo
Presented by the Irish Film Institute as part of the International Culture Programme to celebrate Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union
Supported by Culture Ireland and The Arts Council of Ireland

Saint-Patrick’s Day, Irish Presidency of the European Union, Irish Film Institute.

description:
Cill Aodáin
Choral Society


European Union Performance

March2013

Admission Free

Everyone Welcome


The Cill Aodáin Choral Society would like to thank Jim Higgins, MEP and their family and friends for making this trip  to Brussels possible.

 

Irish in Europe Art & Photo 50 day  Exhibition will remain open until 9pm on Tuesday for vistors to the performance.

The Cill Aodáin Choral Society is an award winning SATB choir from County Mayo in Ireland. The members hail from Kiltimagh and the surrounding areas. From its formation in 1998, the Cill Aodáin Choral Society has grown in members and experience. With over 50 members, the choir meets weekly to share their love for music and singing. The Cill Aodáin Choral Society have received numerous awards at Choral Festivals around Ireland, all the while exploring a wide range of musical genres; from Musical Theatre to Gospel Song, Irish Traditional Ballads to Classical pieces. In recent years the choir have performed with household names such as Rebecca Storm, Tommy Flemming, Liam Lawton, Sean Keane and up-and-coming soprano Anna-Louise Costello. They have also performed on national television. The choir enjoys what they do and are always willing to try new things and face new musical challenges.

Programme at Halles Saint Gery on Tuesday 26 March at 19.00.
New York, New York
Sally Gardens
Hard Times
One Voice (with Anna-Louise Costello)
Last Rose of Summer (Anna-Louise Costello)
Fiddler of Dooney (Anna-Louise Costello)
Amigos Para Sempre (with Anna-Louise Costello)
Ascot Gavotte
For the Beauty of the Earth
Anois Teacht an Earraigh (with Sile Burke)
Ellis Island
Ireland’s Call (with Anna-Louise Costello)
I Dreamt I Dwelt in Marble Halls (Anna-Louise Costello)
The Prayer
Rejoice (Anna-Louise Costello)
Hallelujah Chorus

Finola Higgins-Cosgrove
Finola Higgins-Cosgrove is the musical director of the Cill Aodáin Choral Society. She has an honours degree in Music from NUI Maynooth. She has 17 years teaching, conducting and directing experience. Finola is the musical director and conductor of two award winning choirs. She is also a founding director of the Mayo School of Music.

Anna-Louise Costello
Anna-Louise Costello, from Kiltimagh in Mayo, has a B.Mus Hons from DIT Conservatory of Music as well as a Masters Hons. in Vocal Performance from the Royal Academy of Music, London. Her past performances include performing a gala concert of Moore’s Irish Melodies in the St. Petersburg Arts Institute, Russia as well as performing the part of Zirphile in UK premiere of Rameau’s Acante et Cephise.

Ausra Kvietkute
Ausra is a Lithuanian piano player and music teacher and has a Masters degree in Music. She has been performing and teaching since 1996 and has been involved with many choirs in her years as a piano player and accompanist. She was commended for her “sensitive” accompaniment at a recent choral festival in Sligo, in which she accompanied the Cill Aodáin Choral Society.

Nearest Metro: Debroukere


Please feel free to check out Cill Aodáin Choral Society on Facebook
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Cill-Aodáin-Choral-Society

description:
The Cork-Brussels 1881 History Lecture at Halles Saint Gery

This  lecture will give you an insight into what happened in Cork when the Princess Street Extension to the English Market built in 1881 the same year  when the Saint Gery Market was built in Brussels which is the venue to the Irish in Europe Art and Photo Exhibition. Mr.  Kieran Mc Carthy , Cork Historian and Member of Cork City Council will deliver the lecture. There are now direct flights between Brussels and Cork with Aer Lingus.Tourist and heritage information will be available at the info stand at the Art &Photo Exhibition with details of day tours from Cork on offer from Happy Tours.


The Cork History will be given in English. Mr. Yves Swaelus,Director of Les Halles Saint-Gery Patrimoine et Culture asbl will deliver the welcome address to the lecture given by Councilor Kieran Mc Carthy..

Few people realise that Irish name for Cork means marsh or swamp and the original name for Brussels is marsh or swamp and both grew and evolved from monastic settlements.


About Kieran McCarthy

http://corkheritage.ie/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/kieran-river-lee-300x214.jpgFor over nineteen years,Kieran has actively promoted Cork’s history and heritage and its various communities and people.He has led and continues to lead successful initiatives through  local history talks, City and County school heritage programmes, historical walking tours of Cork, newspaper articles on Cork’s history as well as books and my work through my heritage consultancy business.

He graduated from University College Cork in 1999 with a Joint Honours Bachelor of Arts Degree in Geography and Archaeology. Kieran subsequently completed a Masters of Philosophy in Geography in the Department of Geography, UCC. He has lectured widely at academic and popular level on the Cork region’s past, present and future in association with numerous institutions, in particular University College Cork, Cork City and Cork County Councils, the Cork Education Support Centre, the Vocational Educational Committee and with various community associations within the Cork area and further afield in Cork’s twinned cities, such as San Francisco and its Irish Cultural Centre. He has  been involved in the compilation of several television reports for RTE and TV3 on various aspects of Cork’s history.

In particular, he has  a keen interest in disseminating knowledge about the importance of local studies in Cork’s primary and post-primary schools. Since 2003, I have annually co-ordinated the Discover Cork: Schools’ Heritage Project open to Cork City and County schools. The project focuses on celebrating, highlighting, debating and framing new and relevant approaches to Cork’s cultural heritage for Cork’s youth, teachers and the wider community.

http://corkheritage.ie/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/kieran-in-the-european-parliament-300x225.jpgSince 1999, he has  written a local history and heritage column in the Cork Independent, a weekly Cork newspaper in which he has  been writing a series on the history, geography and the intersection of modern day life in communities in Cork City and County. He is the author of eleven books (http://corkheritage.ie/?page_id=1181).

He was elected to Cork City Council in June 2009 as an Independent (Local Governmnent) City Councillor for the south east ward of Cork City (see www.kieranmccarthy.ie for more on my work in Cork City Council).

description:
Live at Aloft Brussels Schuman - April 3, 2013 at 7pm


LIVE AT ALOFT BRUSSELS SCHUMAN: UNLOCK DIALOGUE

Once again, Aloft are bringing you the hottest emerging artists right in the heart of Brussels, including live, unplugged performances once a month at our w xyz bar from the best of the Belgian scene.
Join us for a free, live, acoustic set: sit back and enjoy one of our exclusive cocktails with a unique artist

 

 

This month's unique performance includes:


UNLOCK DIALOGUE
Established since spring 2009, Unlock Dialogue worked intensively on a few songs with their own character with a cocky guitar and personal texts to the fore. Their first demo "Demo 2009: Unlock Dialogue" opened many doors for them and gave the band the opportunity to perform several fine performances. In 2010, the band released its 2nd demo album "Demo 2010: Melody, oh mellow me!". The following year remained equally active with "Demo 2011: Ignorance is charming". Since then, the band is now focusing on their live performances.


When: April 3, 2013
Time: 7 pm
Where: Aloft Brussels Schuman, Place Jean Rey, 1040 Brussels
Are you thirsty?
2 for 1 happy hours are available from 6pm to 6.30pm and 8pm to 8.30pm

description:
The 50 day Irish in Europe Art and Photo Exhibition Continues at Halles Saint Gery. See all the event details on our event list. On the first Sunday of every month the Vintage Craft Fair  takes place at Halles Saint Gery between 12.00 and 18.00 and thousands will attend this event. We will be taking down some of the paintings to make room for this fair but all the photo exhibits will remain on display. We need volunteers to watch the exhibits and also help distribute Irish Tourist information in six languages to the visitors at the info stand. If you can come along and help for a few hours,let us know at [masked] - your help would be greatly appreciated.

 

Volunteers are also sought for every day as well. It is a great experience learning about Irish Art and Irish Culture and where to visit in Ireland.

description:
Live Trad Irish concert on European Tour from Westport, Ireland

European Premiere Pre-launch CD Concert-

Admission Free -

Follow up concert on Tuesday 16 April!!!!

Also visit the Irish in Europe Art and Photo Exhibition - Brussels Meets Westport

David Ellis Multi-instrumentalist :David Ellis’ musical career began some 30 years ago in Westport, County Mayo, Ireland. Having established himself as a proficient musician, he then went on to travel throughout Europe, teaching and showcasing his instrumental skills as well as, for several years, studying local traditional and folk music. For a number of years Ellis has worked extensively with Mayo Community Arts, creating music workshops in schools and community centres around rural Mayo and is also actively involved with the international charity Haven and traveled to Haiti in 2009 as a volunteer. The years have seen Ellis play with a multitude of artists but more recently has joined forces with fellow musicians Brian Duffy and Olcan Masterson to create the Irish trad trio ‘Last Night’s Seisiun.' Their debut album is a collection of live recordings to be released at Halles Saint Gery 2013.

 

Brian Duffy Singer/songwriter: Brian Duffy is a native of Westport, County Mayo, Ireland. From an early age music developed naturally for him and began performing from age of ten and has been immersed in music ever since. From age 17 Duffy took his work abroad and traveled extensively throughout the world playing, singing and writing music while absorbing different influences along the way. In 2012 Duffy released his debut album of original recordings ‘I Am So…’ In 2013, along with fellow musicians David Ellis and Olcan Masterson, they formed the Irish trad trio ‘Last Night’s Seisiun. Their debut album is slated for release April 2013 entitled ‘Last Night’s Seisiun Live.’ Brian Duffy lives in Westport and performs both as a solo artist and as a member of ‘Last Night’s Seisiun.’

Olcan Masterson is a Traditional Irish musician and composer and plays Irish whistle and flute and his musical influences come from his mother’s musical family from the Glens of Antrim. Masterson has played musical festivals in the USA, Europe and Scanandavia and is a seisiun musician with various folk groups in Westport, Co. Mayo, Ireland and in Europe. Masterson is also a Visitors and Photo Guide for Co Mayo, where his father’s family originated from the Westport and Islands areas. He now resides in Aghagower; a Patrician village founded by St Patrick in 441 AD, where Olcan's musical heritage is still being nurtured .

 

Westport to be promoted in the Heart of Europe

Westporthas been selected by the Irish in Europe Association as the town in Ireland under the ´Brussels Irish Village Project´ to be actively promoted in Europe as a holiday destination from March 17, 2013 to March 16, 2014.

The Saint Patrick’s Day Parade Committee of the Irish in Europe Association each year since 2009 designates in the Schuman Area of the EU Quarter in Brussels an Area to be known as the ´Irish Village´ to be named after a town in Ireland with cultural, trade or heritage significance and on a rotational basis. The EU Quarter includes the Schuman/Park Cinquantenaire in the European Union District. This location was chosen because of the high concentration of Irish businesses already in the area, its excellent public transport connections, its position in the heart of the EU Quarter, and its close proximity to Park Cinquantenaire-the location of the annual Saint Patrick’s Day Parade of the Nations and Regions. Some 20,000 EU officials and diplomats work in this Area.

The Irish Village which is named after a town on a rotational basis, whose purpose is to promote Irish and Irish Diaspora culture, hosts many Irish cultural activities during the annual Irish in Europe Féile. The Parade Committee shortlist a number of towns in Ireland for the twinning project before their final selection. The chosen town in the Irish Village Area is then extensively promoted over a year long period in Brussels, Belgium and across Europe.

This year Westport town is chosen because of its outstanding achievements and accolades it received in Ireland in recent years to include:

*  Westport Voted the Best Place to Live in Ireland 2012

*   Westport Ireland ’s Tidiest Large Town 2012

*  Westport ’s Retail Excellence Ireland Award 2012

Westport has  97 voluntary associations, each working “hand in glove”, creating a fantastic community environment with facilities making it a wonderful place to live, work, shop and holiday in. It is not just a pretty place; it is a jewel in the crown in the West of Ireland along the Atlantic Way.  The Irish in Europe Association in selecting Westport recognises the public expression of the work countless individuals undertake to build community spirit and make their local area a better place to live´. It will serve model town to demonstrate community spirit and active citizenship for all villages, towns and cities in Europe.

Westport with its vibrant shops and restaurants topped the list of towns which were graded on several criteria’s including the range of restaurants, bars and shops on offer, its family friendliness, the availability and price of parking and the areas low crime rate.

The nomination of Westport will not only help the town and its Mayo county hinterland to attract more visitors but serve as an anchor gate-way town to the entire West of Ireland and help create a greater awareness of the region and grow marketing opportunities to generate more tourist numbers to justify additional direct flights from Continental Europe to Knock Airport. It will also complement the Irish Gathering Project in 2013 and get additional and unique coverage in Brussels during Ireland’s Presidency of the European Union from January to July 2013.

description:
Irish Documentary Festival

- The Leuven Institute for Ireland in Europe

Presented by the Irish Film Institute as part of the International Culture Programme to celebrate Ireland’s Presidency of the European Union. They we will be screening Irish made documentaries at The Leuven Institute for Ireland in Europe throughout April, May and June. Next Tuesday, April 30 at 19:30 they will be screening the wonderful His & Hers.
“A man loves his girlfriend the most, his wife the best, but his mother the longest.” Old Irish Proverb.
From kitchens, living rooms, and hallways across the Irish midlands, His & Hers delightfully combines observation and charm to tell a 90-year-old love story through the voices of 70 women. This intimate gender and cultural snapshot explores a woman’s relationships with the men in her life—father, boyfriend, husband, son. Following sequentially from little girl to old woman, each character portrait is woven with the others into one perfectly crafted cinematic quilt.
His & Hers is an enchanting and affectionate appreciation for woman in all her versatility. Award-winning short film director Ken Wardrop (Undressing My Mother, The Herd) has applied his signature style, marking an accomplished feature debut.
His & Hers won the Audience award in the Dublin International Film Festival, The Feature Award in the Galway Film Fleadh, an IFTA for Best Feature Documentary and the Cinematography Award at the Sundance Film Festival 2010.


Tickets are €5. Contact [masked] for bookings.
For more information, please visit their website: http://www.leuveninstitute.eu/php/newsroom/details.php?doc_id=746

3000 Leuven

description:
Exhibition: Strangers to Citizens : The Irish in Continental Europe
3rd – 24th May 2013 as part of the Irish Presidency of the EU Council of Ministers.
Free admission - all welcome

Strangers to Citizens : The Irish in Continental Europe is an exhibition charting the storied history of Irish men and women who migrated to continental Europe in the 17th and 18th centuries. These political, religious and economic refugees – soldiers, lords, priests, businessmen and workers – faced an uncertain future abroad, but over time formed communities and eventually integrated into their host societies. “Strangers to Citizens” provides a fascinating visual history of this journey.

The exhibition is open to Monday – Friday from 10h – 17h.

The exhibition will be on display at the Europe Info Europa at Schuman roundabout in Brussels (1 Rue Archimede, 1000 Brussels). Admission is free.

name: Strangers to Citizens- Exhibition to May 24th.

Festival Matongé-Europe


Volunteers wanted!
Do you work or live in the European quarter or in Matonge? This involves you! The first edition of the Matonge-Europe Festival, a cross-districts Festival on the clichés on the difference, will take place from 5 to 9 June 2013 in this area. Its aim is to promote meetings between the users of both quarters.

Over a period of five days, several social events will be held: a freestyle football competition on the European Parliament esplanade, a modern ball, a parade, a debate on clichés, artists' exhibits, a photographic itinerary, performances, concerts, etc.

Come and join us as a volunteer at the Festival Matongé-Europe. The first “volunteer” meeting took place on 25 April. We are now organizing a second meeting. Interested? Come and join us on Tuesday 7 May at 6.30 p.m. at the Brussels-Europe Liaison Office, 63 avenue d'Auderghem in 1040 Brussels, where amongst others Rebecca Shelley’s project ‘Where is Matonge-Europe?’ will be presented.

description:
Brussels 'Like a Tree' Exhibition opens at Cork International Airport
9 May (Europe Day) to June 23....as part of the Irish in Europe Association Cultural Exchange Program with Ireland.....

 

The Brussels ‘Like a Tree’ Exhibition comes to Cork on Europe Day

This exhibition presents the Brussels Capital Region in a unique perspective showing Trees and Nature against a backdrop of its architectural heritage of urban planning. The Photographic Exhibition is by Luc Teper of the Paul Hankar Institute of Brussels. The photographs were taken over a 2 year period and the project is truly a labour of love by Luc Teper showing the richness and the so often’ taken for granted value’ of trees in our local environments. The contrasts, natural beauty and use of light are stunning and will certainly leave you with a lasting impression of the need and desire to plant a tree in your garden or in your local park or indeed protect it!!

The “ Like a Tree’ Exhibition was exhibited in parallel with the recent 50 Day Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition – Cork Meets Brussels – Brussels Meets Westport at Halles Saint Gery Cultural Centre in the heart of Brussels.
“Bringing Brussels and Ireland closer together in Europe”
This Irish Exhibition was organised in association with THE GALLERY - KINSALE and now to reciprocate the holding of the Irish exhibition in Brussels , the IEAI are happy to organise in association with THE GALLERY KINSALE, the Paul Hankar Institute and Halles Saint Gery Cultural Centre in the exhibiting of the ‘Like a Tree’ Exhibition in Ireland and which will go on tour in Ireland and opens on May 9 at Cork International Airport at 17.30 and run until June 23.

The Irish in Europe Association (International)aisbl( IEAI) (founded in 2011) objectives include the promotion of Irish culture as a means of integration and also the promotion of Cultural Exchange programmes between Belgium and Ireland.
The opening of this exhibition serves as the launch of the cultural exchange program in Ireland to celebrate the friendship that exists between Ireland and Belgium. It also will create awareness of the greater cultural and socio-economic opportunities that now exist with the introduction of the Aer Lingus Direct flights between Cork and Brussels and also ensure the continuity and the expansion of the service as demand for the flights grows.

 

PRESS RELEASE ISSUED BY THE GALLERY-KINSALE

Like a Tree Photo Exhibition at Cork Airport
This month there is a unique exhibition running at Cork International Airport. The “Like a Tree” exhibition is a photo exhibition capturing the beauty & nature of Brussels Capital Region numerous trees & accompanying wildlife.
Not always recognised for its beauty as a city due to its predominant political status Brussels is a well kept secret for a weekend break away. This exhibition helps towards exposing Brussels for its natural beauty & cultural vibrancy.
The exhibition fittingly opens on Europe day (May 9th) & runs until 23rd June.
The Gallery Kinsale is curating the exhibition on the back of a very successful exhibition in Brussels at Halles Saint Gery in association the Irish in Europe Association (International)aisbl and with its many partners & contributors from Cork and around Ireland.
It is hoped to maximise this unique event to promote Belgium as a holiday destination and particularly support the recently introduced direct flights from Cork’s International Airport to Brussels.
Indeed the many Trees that are part of Brussels to be seen in this exhibition relate closely to the landscape of Cork City & that isn’t where the similarities end between the two regions. Did you know the word Brussels comes from the word for Marsh like Cork & it also was built on a monastic site like Cork was & today both cities share many similarities from their non-uniform house structures to many underground rivers & canals from their marsh beginnings.
Brussels is really considered as a green city where trees are considered as a key esthetical part of their urban landscape enhancing the quality of life for its inhabitants just as it is in Cork
Luc Teper has taken his photographs of the Brussels’s trees over a two year period catching their beauty from the early morning till the late evening & it is an exercise well worthwhile when you see the exhibition he has brought before us.
Speaking of the exhibition Ken Buckley of The Gallery Kinsale said
“This is the first time we have curated a photography exhibition & I couldn’t imagine starting at a higher level, the standard of excellence in these photos is second to none & I would encourage all photographers, nature lovers and anyone with an interest in beauty to visit the exhibition & enjoy Lucs work”
Luc is teacher at Paul Hankar Institute in Brussels who have travelled with Luc to Cork for the opening on May 9th. Photography is his passion and his favourite themes are nature but also of the cities that have a deep cultural tradition such as Bruges, Venice and Brussels where he was born and where he is still living and working today. I am sure after Lucs visit to Cork we may well be visiting an exhibition of Corks natural beauty in Brussels in the future & I can see the title already….”Like a Tree”.. Like!”

For further information press information
Contact Ken Buckley ,THE GALLERY-KINSALE
+353 (0)[masked]
name: Brussels 'Like a Tree' Exhibition at Cork International Airport 9 May to June 23

Dear Citizens of the Nations and Regions,

The Irish in Europe Association (International) AISBL takes great pleasure in launching ‘Music of the European Nations & Regions´ at Halles Saint Géry (venue of the 2013 Irish in Europe Art and Photo Exhibition) as part of the annual celebrations of the Brussels Saint Patrick’s Day Parade of the Nations and Regions. Our Parade is an Irish-in-Europe and a Europe-in-Ireland project - Ireland and Europe joined together by a union of people of different nations and regions. Our Parade allows citizens of all cultures to come together to´ wear the green´ and celebrate our European ideals and values on March 17.

2013 is a special year for Éire-Ireland as it celebrates its 40th Anniversary of the European Union and its 7th Presidency of the European Union Council of Ministers during the European Year of Citizens. Hence the Year Theme of the Irish in Europe Association is ´Leadership through Active Citizenship´.

We congratulate Dénes Dosztán, a gifted musician and teacher of piano and violin, on this very appropriate arrangement of music on the piano that helps connect all citizens to the musical heritage and traditions of the Nations and Regions of the European Union.
‘Music of the European Nations and Regions’ is one of our ongoing collaborations with
Dénes Dosztán that started with his performance at the EU Hungarian Presidency–Irish Cultural Fusion event in 2011 at the Aloft Brussels Schuman and continued with the Bloomsday Irish-Hungarian evenings in Brussels, his residency of the Cork Jazz Festival Club of Brussels and the commissioning of Ragtime & Jazz with Irish Melodies CD for the Parade celebrations in 2012.

We wish Dénes continuous success with all his music projects and his international career. We look forward to many more years of collaborating with him.

Denis J. Buckley
International President
The Irish in Europe Association (International) AISBL
Brussels
[masked]


Dénes Dosztán (b. 1984) received a diploma of eminence as violinist and violin teacher in 2008 at the Faculty of Music of the University of Debrecen, Hungary. In 2011 he finished his studies as a master in music - violin performance at the Royal Conservatory of Brussels. He regularly performs as a pianist, as well, classical music, Irish melodies, ragtime and early jazz, including solo or in ensemble. Apart from Serbia and Hungary, Dénes has performed at concerts in Austria, Belgium, Britain, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Slovakia and Switzerland. Since 2013 Dénes Dosztán has been working as the resident artist of the Cork Jazz Festival Club of Brussels under the patronage of the Irish in Europe Association. Website: www.denesdosztan.com


________________________

,,I met Dénes Dosztán years ago in Hungary and I have a great souvenir about meeting him. His personality was very strong and charming. I had a wonderful feeling about this young artist. I recently heard his piano playing and I have to say that I am amazed about the clarity and precision of his technique. But the most important part for me is that he touches my soul in his rendition of the slower tunes. I highly recommend this young musician to your attention."
Mimi Blais, pianist, „Queen of Ragtime” (Quebec, Canada)

,,Dénes is not only a versatile, excellent artist – who can adapt himself to his environment with an unbelievable artistical sense in order to exploit the maximum of his vocation –, but has been my true friend since 10 years, in whom I can discover myself." Nándor Fekete, concert organist


,,Energy, authenticity, sensibility and versatility are the keywords that describe the young and talented Dénes Dosztán."
Benjamin Intartaglia, pianist, composer, organist (Paris, France)

Photo by Kristóf Baráti
name: 'Music of the European Nations & Regions'Irish Premiere in Cork May 9 Europe Day

description:
Internal Combustion
Following the success of our last workshop, small hushed waves are pleased to present the Internal Combustion workshop, a half-day course designed to give your stories drive and get them moving.
The workshop is open to writers of all levels of experience, and will be based around discussions and writing exercises, to explore how to give your story the dramatic fuel it needs.
Although the focus of the morning will be on short stories, the focus on the mechanics of storytelling means that workshop is also perfect for writers of longer fiction, plays and screenplays, and even poetry.
Come with an idea for a story and we’ll explore ways to make that story work.
The workshop will be held in Sterling Books on Sunday 12th May.
Address: Rue du Fossé aux Loups 38, 1000 Brussels
Email: [masked]
The workshop will run from 14:00 to 17:00 with a break for coffee. The fee is €15.
Please bring writing materials.
And here’s our blog: http://smallhushedwaves.blogspot.be/2013/05/internal-combustion.html
Looking forward to seeing you on the day!

description:
Last opportunity to view this Exhibition at the BOZAR finishing up on the 19 May.
Bozar has chosen to pay tribute to the genius of Francis Bacon as well as the talents of a subsequent generation of Irish artists. Metro Gare Central

Open 10 am to 6pm...late opening on Thursday to 9pm.

Changing States meditates on the pluralist nature of contemporary Irish art. Through multivalent viewpoints Irish artists have examined the forces beneath the layered complexities of their political, social, economic and cultural territories. In an increasingly globalised society their art is a questioning of ideology and a testing of alternatives, by addressing selfhood and collectivity. Changing States features contemporary Irish artworks alongside studio material, unfinished canvases and paintings from the Francis Bacon Studio. The exhibition draws on the impressive collections of the Irish Museum of Modern Art and Dublin City Gallery the Hugh Lane.
name: Changing States: Contemporary Irish Art at the Francis Bacon Studio -Final Days

description:
The Importance of Being Earnest, A Trivial Comedy for Serious People is a play by Oscar Wilde. First performed on 14 February 1895 at St. James's Theatre in London, it is a farcical comedy in which the protagonists maintain fictitious personæ in order to escape burdensome social obligations. Working within the social conventions of late Victorian London, the play's major themes are the triviality with which it treats institutions as serious as marriage, and the resulting satire of Victorian ways. Contemporary reviews all praised the play's humour, though some were cautious about its explicit lack of social messages, while others foresaw the modern consensus that it was the culmination of Wilde's artistic career so far. Its high farce and witty dialogue have helped make The Importance of Being Earnest Wilde's most enduringly popular play.
The successful opening night marked the climax of Wilde's career but also heralded his downfall. The Marquess of Queensberry, father of Lord Alfred Douglas, an intimate friend of Wilde, planned to present Wilde a bouquet of rotten vegetables and disrupt the show. Wilde was tipped off and Queensberry was refused admission. Soon afterwards, however, their feud came to a climax in court, where Wilde's homosexual double life was revealed to the Victorian public and he was eventually sentenced to imprisonment. Wilde's notoriety caused the play, despite its success, to be closed after just 86 performances. After his release, he published the play from exile in Paris, but he wrote no further comic or dramatic work.

The Importance of Being Earnest by Oscar Wilde
Directed by Andrew McIlroy

The Irish Theatre Group is very proud to present The Importance of Being Earnest at Palais Des Beaux-Arts Studio.
Andrew McIIroy's exciting new take on Oscar Wilde's classic sparkles, while never losing sight of the dark satire behind the facade of glittering comedy.
Wit, intrigue and passion are to the fore in this tale of true love and finding ones way through the pretences and artifices of social existence.
Visually and emotionally powerful, the ITG's Importance of Being Earnest has brought the finest talent together to create a theatrical event worthy of the Irish Presidency of the Council of the European Union.
As Wilde said of the philosophy of The Importance of Being Earnest, "...we should treat all the trivial things of life seriously and all the serious things of life with a sincere and studied triviality." The ITG's Importance of Being Earnest promises to be an trivially serious evenings theatre.

This production is supported by the Irish Presidency of the Council of the European Union.
Centre for Fine Arts / Studio

Over half the tickets already sold for The Importance of Being Earnest
Last few remaining tickets with Friday and Saturday almost completely sold out.

"I' ve now realised for the first time in my life the vital Importance of Being Earnest."

Just under a week to go and, thanks to the incredible demand for tickets to our next show, They only have a few tickets left for Friday and Saturday night with the other three nights not far behind.


If you have been delaying getting your ticket then this is the time to get back into Lady Bracknell' s good books.
Tickets can be purchased directly from the BOZAR website, by telephone (02/[masked]) or in person.
It takes a long time and a lot of hard dedicated work from a lot of people to put on a show like this.
They have once again pulled together a dedicated multinational cast and crew who have been working tirelessly for many months.
We have laughed together, we have cried, we have argued and then we have laughed a lot more.


Our moment in the spotlight is almost upon us and all too soon it will be over.
We are putting the finishing touches to the Andrew McIIroy' s exciting new take on Oscar Wilde's classic and are so much looking forward to sharing with you the results of all our hard work.
It will be fun, noisy, energetic and alternative, Wilde would hopefully have approved.
Lady Bracknell: I am glad, however, that he made up his mind at the last to some definite course of action.
We look forward to seeing you there!

The Importance of Being Earnest, at Palais des Beaux-Arts Studio, running from Tuesday 21st to Saturday 25th May.
This production is supported by the Irish Presidency of the Council of the European Union.

The Brussels Liaison Office strives to turn Brussels natives into Europeans and Europeans into Brussels natives, which is why we organise the Matonge-Europe Festival, in collaboration with various other partners.
This cross-neighbourhood festival on 'the clichés of difference’ is aimed at bringing two Brussels neighbourhoods and their residents closer together by means of social, artistic and sports events, such as a concert, parade or football match. How strong are the clichés? Who will cross the boundary? That is exactly what the festival aims to discover!
The Matongé-Europe Festival will take place from 5 to 9 June and is an initiative by the Brussels-Europe Liaison Office, Elzenhof community centre, Flemish-African House Kuumba and dance company t.r.a.n.s.i.t.s.c.a.p.e.
You are kindly invited to take part in the festival. Could you please also communicate to all your friends and workd colleagues about this great festival.All information can be found at www.festival-matongeurope.be.

Le Festival Matongé-Europe démarre le 5 juin avec la parade ‘Frites Sauce Manioc’, une parade colorée, joviale, bruyante et métissée! Elle est menée par la compagnie t.r.a.n.s.i.t.s.c.a.p.e et son école de danse “La Confiserie”, Monyama asbl, Mbanza asbl, les Choux d’XL asbl, Les Vrais Majors et encadrée par … Zinneke!

Point d’info: Kuumba, rue de la Paix 55, 1050 Ixelles, 14h-18h - tel. [masked] - Métro: Porte de Namur - Bus: 71 & 54 arrêt: St-Boniface
Le Festival Matongé-Europe favorise les rencontres entre les habitants, travailleurs et usagers du quartier Matongé et du quartier européen. Du 5 au 9 juin, ces deux quartiers se découvrent à travers un parcours urbain, une parade, un concert, mais aussi un bal moderne, un tournoi de mini-foot artistique et enfin un forum/brunch sur les clichés de la différence.
Les habitants de ces deux quartiers vivent ensemble, mais se côtoient-ils vraiment ? Où sont les barrières ? Des frontières invisibles existent-elles ? Les clichés sont-ils réels ? Qui traverse ? Voici ce que le festival souhaite découvrir. À Bruxelles, l’Afrique et l’Europe ne sont pas séparées par un océan. Le quartier européen et le quartier Matongé sont bien voisins.

Wanted …..EU Paticipants in the mini-soccer tournament on the esplanade of the European Parliament…

www.festival-matongeurope.be
http://www.facebook.com/pages/Festival-Matong%C3%A9-Europe/528046437246138
name: Matongé-Europe Festival- Brussels  5 June to 9 June

Bloomsday
Irish-Hungarian Brunch
With Music Recital
by Dénes Dosztán
on grand piano
Date: Sunday June 16, 2013 from 12.30 to 14.30
Café Halles Saint Gery
1 Place Saint Gery, 1000 Bruxelles
(Metro Debrouckere -5 minutes walk)
Choose from the restaurant Menu

– Registration advised for logistics:
[masked]


Blooms Day on the 16th of June is celebrated as a holiday by scholars and fans of Ulysses, the novel by James Joyce. It was on this day that the events of the novel took place in Dublin in 1904.
Blooms Day is named after Leopold Bloom - a Hungarian, the middle-aged advertising salesman who is the protagonist of the famous book by Joyce, which was published in 1922.

Come along in the fashion of 1904 or in your own country traditional costume if you wish.
There will be some readings from Ulysses with a special recital by Dénes Dosztán (Violinist, Pianist and Teacher www.denesdosztan.com ) of Irish Melodies and Hungarian music that was played in Hungary and Ireland in 1904
Organised by the Irish in Europe Association (International) AISBL
(Incorporating the Brussels Saint Patrick’s Day Parade Committee)
Irish and Hungarian Tourist Information Stand at Event
All are welcome! Admission free
www.meetup.com/Irish-in-Europe

description:
Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Program

Brussels ‘Like a Tree’ Exhibition’

on Tour in Ireland

By Luc Teper of the Paul Hankar Institute of Brussels

‘Bringing Brussels and Westport closer in Europe’

Photo Exhibition from 29 June to 26 July

Westport Library

The Crescent
Westport

Monday: Closed
Tuesday: 10:00am - 8:00pm
Wednesday: 10:00am - 8:00pm
Thursday: 10:00am - 1:00pm : 2:00pm - 5:00pm
Friday: 10:00am - 1:00pm : 2:00pm - 5:00pm
Saturday: 10:00am - 4:00pm

Admission Free

 

Like a Tree Photo Exhibition at Westport Library

This month there is a unique exhibition running at Westport Library. The “Like a Tree” exhibition presents the Brussels Capital Region in a unique perspective showing Trees and Nature against a backdrop of its architectural heritage of urban planning. The Photographic Exhibition is by Luc Teper of the Paul Hankar Institute of Brussels. The photographs were taken over a 2 year period and the project is truly a labohttp://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/1/c/4/a/event_56167242.jpegur of love by Luc Teper showing the richness and the so often’ taken for granted value’ of trees in our local environments. The contrasts, natural beauty and use of light are stunning and will certainly leave you with a lasting impression of the need and desire to plant a tree in your garden or in your local park or indeed protect it!!


The “ Like a Tree’ Exhibition was exhibited in parallel with the recent 50 Day Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition – “Cork Meets Brussels – Brussels Meets Westport” at Halles Saint Gery Cultural Centre in the heart of Brussels. “Bringing Brussels and Ireland closer together in Europe”
The photo element of the Halles Saint Gery Exhibition is now being exhibited as the Irish in Europe-Galerie Anspach Photo Exhibition to celebrate the final weeks of the Irish Presidency in Brussels. It includes a Paul Hankar media exhibition of the Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange program and the recent visit of Westport town council to Brussels. It is now confirmed that this exhibition will be extended to the end of July to celebrate the 40 anniversary of Ireland’s membership of the European Union. Over half a million visitors will view the Photo Exhibition at Galerie Anspach.
The ‘Like a Tree ‘exhibition opens Saturday June 29th and runs until 26th July which is curated by “The Gallery Kinsale” on the back of the very successful exhibition in Brussels at Halles Saint Gery.
Indeed the many Trees that are part of Brussels to be seen in this exhibition relate closely to the landscape of Westport & that isn’t where the similarities end between the two regions.
Brussels is really considered as a green city where trees are considered as a key esthetical part of their urban landscape enhancing the quality of life for its inhabitants just as it is in Westport.

The word Mhaigh Eo means "the plain of the Yew Tree" & Westport has enjoyed a strong tree heritage over the centuries that continues to this day.
Luc Teper has taken his photographs of the Brussels’s trees over a two year period catching their beauty from the early morning till the late evening & it is an exercise well worthwhile when you see the exhibition he has brought before us.
Speaking of the exhibition Ken Buckley of The Gallery Kinsale said
“This is the first time we have curated a photography exhibition & I couldn’t imagine starting at a higher level, the standard of excellence in these photos is second to none & I would encourage all photographers, nature lovers and anyone with an interest in beauty to visit the exhibition & enjoy Lucs work”
Luc is a teacher at Paul Hankar Institute in Brussels who have travelled with Luc to Westport for the opening on Saturday June 29th. The Exhibition will be Officially opened at 11.00am at Westport Library by Cllr Michael McLaughlin, Cathaoirleach of Westport Town Council.
Photography is his passion and his favourite themes are nature but also of the cities that have a deep cultural tradition such as Bruges, Venice and Brussels where he was born and where he is still living and working today. I am sure after Luc’s visit to Westport and his love of natural beauty we may well be visiting an exhibition of Westport in Brussels in the future.
END

About The Irish in Europe Association -
The Irish in Europe Association (International)aisbl( IEAI) (founded in 2011) objectives include the promotion of Irish culture as a means of integration and also the promotion of Cultural Exchange programmes between Belgium and Ireland.
The opening of this exhibition serves as the continuation of the cultural exchange program in Ireland to celebrate the friendship that exists between Ireland and Belgium.
Useful Links –
http://www.westporttc.ie/home/index.aspx
www.thegallerykinsale.com 
http://www.meetup.com/Irish-in-Europe/
http://www.europost.bg/article?id=7980
name: Brussels 'Like a Tree' Exhibition at Westport-Ireland

description:
Sixth Annual European Theme Special Claddagh Toastmasters Meeting to celebrate 2013 European Year of the Citizens

All friends of Toastmasters and Irish in Europe Members,Members of the Belgian and International Community are invited to the sixth Annual European Theme Special Claddagh Toastmasters Meeting

To celebrate and create awareness for the 2013 European Year of the Citizens
Thursday August 1st, 18.45 to 21.00
The European Year of Citizens 2013 is dedicated to the rights that come with EU citizenship. Over this year, we will encourage dialogue between all levels of government, civil society and business at events and conferences around Europe to discuss those EU rights and build a vision of how the EU should be in 2020.
For more information:http://europa.eu/citizens-2013/.

Everyone welcome-admission free. Please let your friends know about this meeting!

The format for this meeting will be different from Normal Club meetings.
1. Marathon Table Topic Session - Speakers will be allowed to speak up to 3 minutes if they so wish. There will no be no evaluation of table topics. The objective is to encourage members and guests to contribute to the meeting and stimulate discussion.
2. After the Coffee Break will have some prepared speeches on the theme subject and based on speech objectives. Speeches will not receive oral evaluation but instead written ones.
3. Following the prepared speeches, there will be an open forum discussion with panel discussion with audience participation with the Toastmaster of the evening serving as Moderator. Persons who deliver prepared speeches and some persons who speak on table topics will be invited to serve on the panel.
4. The meeting will adjourn to a local pub afterwards afterwards for a social and network drink and the Claddagh Club will go into summer recess until September 5th. However there will be other social events in between.

We also invite Toastmaster members and guests to submit subjects in advance to [masked] that you would like to be covered in the table topics session and or in the open forum discussion.
Everyone welcome-admission free. Please let your friends know about this meeting!
Regards,
Yvonne Mc Grory
VP Education
- Claddagh Toastmasters
http://tmclub.eu/portal.php?page=225
http://sites.google.com/site/claddaghtoastmasters/
1st and 3rd Thursday of the month, welcome coffee at 6.45 pm.
Meeting starts at 7pm sharp.
Quaker House, Square Ambiorix 50, 1000 Brussels
Ring the Quaker House Bell to gain entry.
The Claddagh Toastmasters club can help you to develop your public speaking and communication skills in English or Gaeilge in a fun and social environment with an international group. You can attend a club meeting as a guest to see what it's like.

description:
“Brussels 40 - Clonakilty 400 Exhibition”
                         An Art Nouveau evolution in Europe.
                           Student Photo Exhibition
                             Featuring the work of Paul Hankar Institute, Brussels, Belgium.

Clonakilty Community Arts Centre in association with The Gallery Kinsale under the auspices of The Irish in Europe Association present the Paul Hankar Institute Brussels “Brussels 40 - Clonakilty 400 Exhibition” Art Nouveau in Europe photo exhibition featuring the work of Paul Hankar Institute’s Interior Design Students.

“Brussels 40 - Clonakilty 400 Exhibition” offers an overview of Art Nouveau style in Europe from late 19th till early 20th century. Influenced by taste and culture, each European city developed variant Art Nouveau style, some more floral some more geometric. This exhibition aims to demonstrate the Art Nouveau style diversity in Europe through decorative and architectural details.
For this project the students were inspired by how iron, a rough and functional material, took an aesthetic dimension during the Art Nouveau movement. Actualising to a modern material, they used cardboard giving it a new aesthetic and functional definition. By this, another societal trend was highlighted, that of recycling.
By giving a second life to these cardboard boxes that have traveled from exhibition to exhibition, stirring up curiosity, a dynamic wall stands before the visitor to make him discover an overview of Art Nouveau style diversity in Europe.

Celebrating Ireland’s 40 years EU membership, the relationship with Brussels the EU capital and the 400th anniversary of Clonakilty Town’s foundation, this exhibition symbolises the continuation of cultural exchange projects between Brussels and Cork. This cooperation is availed by the new direct Cork - Brussels Aer Lingus flights.


Speaking of the project, Clonakilty Community Arts Centre Chairperson Clodagh Connaughton said “We are delighted to be hosting this exhibition as the arts centre is all about our community and with a significant expatriate Belgian population in Clonakilty, it was fitting for our town and our arts centre to be chosen; it is a yet another endorsement of the importance of the centre to the community and the work done here”.

Please join us on Sunday September 29th at 7pm for the exhibition opening.


         Opening times for duration of exhibition: Tues-Sat[masked]pm

                                     Admission Free

For more information visit the Clonakilty Community Art centre website: http://clonakiltycommunityartscentre.weebly.com/
and Facebook page: www.facebook.com/clonarts

venue.name: Clonakilty Community Art Centre - Blue Door 1st. Floor

name: “Brussels 40 - Clonakilty 400 Exhibition” 29 September to 29 October

         Opening times for duration of exhibition: Tues-Sat[masked]pm

                                     Admission Free

For more information visit the Clonakilty Community Art centre website: http://clonakiltycommunityartscentre.weebly.com/
and Facebook page: www.facebook.com/clonarts

description:
3rd. Annual Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday.

The Irish in Europe Association (International) AISBL in compliance with its aims and objectives remembers all Irish and the Irish Diaspora in all armies who died in all wars and conflicts. IEAI in particular remembers the 50,000 Irish who died and estimated 500,000 members of the Irish Diaspora in all Armies who participated during the liberation of Belgium in the first and second world wars.

Let those who come after us see to it that their names be not forgotten
Hence it will have its third Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday in Brussels on Saturday 9 November at 11.30 am. The IEAI will lay a wreath at the Anglo-Belgian War Memorial at Place Poelaert / Poelaertplein in front of Palais de Justice de Bruxelles and across from the Infantry Memorial of Brussels in memory of the Belgian foot soldiers who fought in World War I and II. (Metro or Tram Louise 3 minutes walk). The Anglo-Belgian War Memorial commemorates the heroic Belgian people who helped the Irish and British prisoners of war during World War I. Designed by the British sculptor Charles Sargeant Jagger [masked]), the monument was inaugurated in 1923. The composition, in Brainvilliers stone, features figures of Irish, British and Belgian soldiers. The sides are covered with reliefs representing scenes of Belgian common folk tending to wounded British soldiers. There is also a relief of an Irish harp. A plaster cast of the statues of soldiers can be seen at the Military Museum in Brussels. Following the laying of the wreath, a poem by Irish Poet Francis Ledwidge will be recited. He enlisted in the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers in 1914 and was killed in the battle of Ypres on the 31st July 1917. See www.francisledwidge.com . After the ceremony, guests shall proceed to Mac Sweeney's Irish Pub for warm refreshments at Jean Stasstraat, Brussels 1060 located to the right of Avenue Louise about 7 minutes walk from the memorial. On the way the group shall stop at the site of the former residence in exile of William Smith O Brien, one of the leaders of the Irish Rebellion of 1848 and direct descendent of King Brian Boru who was killed at the Battle of Clontarf in 1014. He also lived in Hungary where he advised the Hungarian Independence Movement. Every one is welcome to come along to the third annual Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday ceremony.
“Your Donation to help defray costs would be much appreciated“

Bank: Centea
Name account: IEAI
Account nr:[masked]
IBAN: BE[masked]
SWIFT/BIC-code: BIC SPAABE22

[masked]

Read about the Irish Peace Tower in Flanders

Irish Peace Tower in Flanders http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Island_of_Ireland_Peace_Park
name: Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday

Musician Profiles.

Dénes Dosztán

www.denesdosztan.com

·  Born in 1984 in Újvidék (now Novi Sad in Serbia)

·   Josip Slavenski Music School between [masked])

·   Zoltán Kodály Secondary School of Music in Kecskemét, Hungary [masked])

·  Faculty of Music of the University of Debrecen, diploma of eminence as violinist and violin teacher [masked]), grade: excellent

·  In the summer of 2004, 2005 and 2006 organising series of concerts for Debrecen music students in cities in northern Serbia, acted as first violinist

·  In 2005 own chamber music ensemble won the Award of Excellence at the Chamber Music Competition of the University of Debrecen

·  In the 2005/6 academic year concertmaster of the string ensemble of the university

·  In 2007/8 State Scholarship of the Republic of Hungary

·  Attending master courses led by violinists Kristóf Baráti, Sándor Devich, Rudolf Fátyol, Géza Kapás, András Kiss, Péter Lissauer, Péter Somogyi, Simon Standage and Takahashi Miki

·  Between 2008 and 2011 studied violin under Katalin Sebestyén at the Royal Conservatory of Brussels and finishing studies as a master in music - violin performance

· [masked] member of the Sebastian String Orchestra in Antwerp

·  Also composing music, solo piano compositions were introduced to the audience by the organist, Nándor Fekete, at the University of Debrecen, Hungary

·  Being also a pianist, on the 6th of November 2010 had a possibility to play a duo concert in Brussels with one of the leading violinists of today, Kristóf Baráti

·  From the year 2011 working as the resident artiste of the “Irish In Europe Association” in Brussels, releasing CDs on Irish Melodies, playing at concerts and other venues. Commissioned by the IEAI to celebrate the Irish Presidency of the European Council of Ministers with European Premier Concert at Halles Saint Gery, Brussels and Irish Premiere at Clarion Hotel, Cork of “Music of the European Nations & Region.

·  22nd of May, 2013 played one of the solo parts of double concerto for two violins, accompanied by the Hungarian Chamber Orchestra, the other violin part was played by Kristóf Baráti. Radio Bartók and the Hungarian National Television broadcasted the concert

·  Apart from Serbia and Hungary,performed at concerts in Austria, Belgium, Britain, France, Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands, Slovakia and Switzerland.

Anikó Koroknai

Anikó Koroknai born on 16-[masked] in Pécs. 
Primary school in Pécs, School in Pécs with emphasis on music (piano )

Lilla Szathmáry , Dr. Dezso Karasszon , Szilárd Kovács , Anne Nietosvaara , Tuomas Karjalainen , Prof. Gunther Rost , Prof. Pieter van Dijk .

description:
Put this event in your new year diary as soon as someone gives you a present of one!Look out for this event at Kitty O' Shea's where the Irish flag was always kept flying in good and bad times......

Irish in Europe Foundation Day & Back to Work & End of Bailout Party

·   Friday 10 January, 2014 from 6:30 PM

Kitty O’ Shea’s Irish Pub and Restaurant

42 Boulevard Charlemagne, 1000, Brussels

(Metro Schuman Berlaymont exit)

</a>

The Irish in Europe Association have their Annual New Year Back to Work and Foundation Day Party.  We also celebrate the end of the bailout by the Troika. A great opportunity to network and also to learn about Irish organisations and Irish social, sporting and cultural activities in Brussels.

Admission Free, Everyone is Welcome!!!

Come Directly after Work?  Kitchen open ……

The Irish in Europe Association celebrate its Foundation Day in January as it was in January 2009 when its Saint Patrick's Day Parade of the Nations & Regions Committee met for the first time.

The Parade is a multicultural opportunity to bring families and community organisations together at one big event, to get to know new comers and to make new friends and bridge the cultural divide with other communities.

  Please let us know if you would like to join our volunteer committees to help to organise the sixth Parade (Sunday March 16),  and our cultural and micro integration events. Persons of all nationalities are welcome to join working groups.

In parallel to the Parade celebrations we will have our annual two month Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition and also Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Program between Belgium and Ireland.

Nominations for the Parade Grand Marshal are now being accepted .An Irish  person or member of the Irish Diaspora who has made an outstanding contribution to civic society in Belgium, Ireland or Europe, or to Irish Culture, or to the well-being of the Irish Diaspora in Europe would be eligible for nomination. Also eligible would be any Irish person who has played a major scientific, entrepreneurial, humanitarian or peace-keeping role in the world.  If you would like to nominate person, please contact nomination committee at <a href="mailto:[masked]">[masked]

Spare Printer?  Have you upgraded your printer and maybe scanner for Christmas? If so would you like to donate your printer to the Irish in Europe Association (International) AISBL?

 
Irish in Europe Association (International) aisbl

(Incorporating the Brussels Saint Patrick’s Day Parade of the Nations & Regions Committee)

www.meetup.com/Irish-in-Europe

Established 2011 by Royal Decree to help the Irish Diaspora and promote

Irish Culture & Integration at local Chapter level

in Europe

description:
2014 Exhibitions - February Two Exhibitions from The Paul Hankar Institute Brussels

Like a Tree

7th - 21st of February

The Brussels “Like a Tree” exhibition is a photo exhibition capturing the beauty & nature of Brussels Capital Region numerous trees & accompanying wildlife.

Not always recognised for its beauty as a city due to its predominant political status Brussels is a well kept secret for a weekend break away. This exhibition helps towards exposing Brussels for its natural beauty & cultural vibrancy.

The Gallery Kinsale is curating the exhibition in anticipation of another successful exhibition in Brussels main visitor and exhibition space; Halle Saint-Gery in association with its many partners & contributors from Brussels & Ireland under the auspices of The Irish in Europe Association (International)aisbl.

It is hoped to maximise this unique event to promote Belgium as a holiday destination and particularly support the recently introduced direct flights from Cork’s International Airport to Brussels.

Indeed the many Trees that are part of Brussels to be seen in this exhibition relate closely to the landscape of Cork City & that isn’t where the similarities end between the two regions. Did you know the word Brussels comes from the word for Marsh like Cork & it also was built on a monastic site like Cork was & today both cities share many similarities from their non-uniform house structures to many underground rivers & canals from their marsh beginnings.

Brussels is really considered as a green city where trees are considered as a key esthetical part of their urban landscape enhancing the quality of life for its inhabitants just as it is in Cork.

Luc Teper has taken his photographs of the Brussels’s trees over two years catching their beauty from the early morning till the late evening & it is an exercise well worthwhile when you see the exhibition he has brought before us.

Luc is a teacher at Paul Hankar Institute in Brussels who recently held an exhibition in their rotunda of their visits to Ireland. Photography is his passion and his favourite themes are nature but also of the cities that have a deep cultural tradition such as Bruges, Venice and Brussels where he was born and where he is still living and working today. I am sure after Lucs visit to Cork we may well be visiting an exhibition of Corks natural beauty in Brussels in the future & I can see the title already….”Like a Tree.. Like!”

Art Nouveau Conceptual Exhibition
This exhibition is the work of Paul Hankar Institute’s Interior Design Students which offers an overview of Art Nouveau style in Europe from late 19th till early 20th century. Influenced by taste and culture, each European city developed variant Art Nouveau style, some more floral some more geometric. This exhibition aims to demonstrate the Art Nouveau style diversity in Europe through decorative and architectural details.

For this project the students were inspired by how iron, a rough and functional material, took an aesthetic dimension during the Art Nouveau movement. Actualising to a modern material, they used cardboard giving it a new aesthetic and functional definition. By this, another societal trend was highlighted, that of recycling.

By giving a second life to these cardboard boxes that have travelled from exhibition to exhibition, stirring up curiosity, a dynamic wall stands before the visitor to make him discover an overview of Art Nouveau style diversity in Europe.

This conceptual presentation was inaugurated in 2013 in Ireland as the “Brussels 40-Clonakilty 400 Exhibition at the Community Arts Centre in Clonakilty to celebrate Ireland’s 40 years of membership of EU and its relationship with Brussels as the EU Capital and also to celebrate the 400 anniversary of the foundation of Clonakilty Town with its Charter. It marked the beginning of the Irish in Europe cultural exchange projects curated by THE GALLERY KINSALE between Brussels and communities in Cork City and County. It has led to the establishment of the West Cork-Belgian Irish Committee. Arising from suggestions generated from the conceptual exhibition, plans are now underway to put in place a Art Nouveau Tourist Trail listing Art Nouveau buildings and designs in Cork. At the recent Irish-Belgian Weekend in January at the Paul Hankar Institute in Brussels, exhibits on display from Clonakilty Artists included Art Nouveau-Celtic fusion exhibits.

The opportunity for both exhibitions to display in tandem at the Cork Vision Centre has added a dynamic visual experience to these exhibitions allowing the viewer to almost experience first-hand a walk through the beautiful city of Brussels. more info at http://www.corkvisioncentre.com/corkvision2/Main/LikeATreeArt.htm
name: Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Exhibition  Program at Cork Vision Centre

description:
Claddagh Toastmasters of Brussels  will host their seventh annual ‘Seachtain na Gaeilge’ lecture in English given by Dr Seán Ó Riain on the history and nature of the Irish language with theme "Why Irish? - An Ghaeilge: Canathaobh?"

Claddagh TOASTMASTERS Bilingual CLUB OF BRUSSELS MÁISTRÍ SLÁINTÍ an Chladaigh – Club Dátheangach na Bruiséile

Claddagh Toastmasters will host their seventh annual ‘Seachtain na Gaeilge’ lecture in English on the history and nature of the Irish language with theme "Why Irish? - An Ghaeilge: Canathaobh?" on Thursday March 6, 2014 at the Quaker House, Square Ambiorix 50, 1000 Brussels(Metro Schuman) "Why Irish? - An Ghaeilge: Canathaobh?"


“Why Irish? With over 10,000 marching on the streets of Dublin on 15 February 2014, and the resignation of the Languages Commissioner last week, the Irish language remains controversial. Some wonder what it is all about. Why does Irish ignite passions, both positive and negative? How does it relate to the culture of modern Ireland? And why do so many Irish people remain emotionally attached to a language most of them do not speak in everyday life? Is Irish of no practical value, as some claim….or could there be another side to the story?”


Come along and find out more on the Irish Language!

It will be preceded by a short demonstration bilingual table topics session. Welcome coffee at 18.45. Given by Dr Seán Ó Riain, Past President of Claddagh Toastmasters, Diplomat and Seconded National Expert at European Commission. Responsible for the Irish-language version of the Commission website, EUROPA, and for making an ongoing contribution to the evolution of language policy.

Admission free including refreshments. Book early to secure a place. Guests will be invited to make a small contribution towards costs of room rental and refreshments. 

Registrations  to Kate Izzo at: [masked]

Dr Seán Ó Riain

- 29 years of diplomatic service in Brussels (EU), Germany, Austria, Poland, Australia. PhD (TCD) on language policy, “Language Planning in Ireland and Québec”. Some legal studies. He has worked for 2.5 years at the European Commission, 16 years at 5 Irish embassies, 11 years in Iveagh House; and 2 years lecturing in Irish at Maynooth University.


Claddagh TOASTMASTERS Bilingual CLUB OF BRUSSELS.

MÁISTRÍ SLÁINTÍ an Chladaigh –Club Dátheangach na Bruiséile
Cabhraíonn Club Máistrí Sláintí an Chladaigh chun do scileanna sa chaint phoiblí, sa phleanáil, san oiliúint agus sa bhainistíocht a fhorbairt. Sa Quaker House, Square Ambiorix 50, 1000 An Bhruiséil (Métro Schuman) a thagann an club le chéile. Caife/fáilte ar 18.45. Is féidir dátaí cruinnithe a athrú i ngeall ar shaoire agus cúinsí eile.


http://sites.google.com/site/claddaghtoastmasters/


www.toastmasters.org
name: Claddagh Toastmasters 7nth. Annual Lecture on the Irish Language

description:
The Parade needs your Support

Dear Friends,

Each year, our Saint Patrick’s Day Parade Committee organises a Parade to mark our National Day of Celebration and showcase Irish culture. This year, we plan to continue this tradition with a sixth one.

Can you help us achieve this? With very little effort, you could! A small donation is all that it takes.

Our Parade is run entirely on a voluntary basis and currently receives no external financial support or funding. Most of the Parade costs in previous years were paid for by contributions from members and volunteers, and by small donations received. But we can’t expect the same people to pay the costs every year. We need “a little help from our friends”.
That’s where you can play your part to make it work. We do expect to expand the Parade format next year as austerity measures phase out in Ireland and Belgium in anticipation that new sources of funding will emerge from private sponsors and cultural bodies. In the mean time, we depend on donations to cover the administrative costs to have an Official Parade. The cost, regardless of the size of the Parade, comes to close to two thousand euro. The engagement of any marching bands or cultural groups and the organisation of Parade-related activities are dependent entirely on having sufficient funds in our bank account or reliable pledges of financial support. Even if you can only make a small contribution, it’s enough to make a difference. It will ensure that the Parade can be successful, enjoyable and good fun.
In order to preserve the historical records of past parades, a new website is being constructed to provide ease of access to all the archives. Many volunteers & supporters of past parades have left Brussels and sadly in some cases, have died. We now recognise the urgent need to have a better permanent record of their contributions. Should you have any photos, written accounts or radio and tv-links from the past parades or of the 2014 parade please contact us:
Many are aware that the Parade Committee served as the impetus that gave rise to the establishment of the Irish in Europe Association (International) aisbl (IEAI).The main function of the IEAI is to help the world wide Irish Diaspora living and working in Europe and promote Irish culture, community building and micro integration in local communities through a network of Chapters in Europe. Membership is open to all nationalities.

The IEAI made a major cultural contribution in 2013 for the year of the Irish Presidency with concerts and exhibitions at Halles Saint Gery & Gallery Anspach with the support of mainly back to back sponsorship. Volunteers manned the exhibitions and helped with the distribution of cultural and tourist information in seven languages promoting the island of Ireland. IEAI also launched the Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange program between Ireland and Belgium. Exhibitions showcasing Brussels are now on tour in Ireland to help build cultural relations. The promotion of the Cork–Brussels direct flights is ongoing and in April, we are back in Halles Saint Gery with the Irish in Europe Photo Exhibition to help promote ‘Limerick City of Culture’ and ‘Sligo European Town of Sport’ with other mini exhibitions to include Irish commemoration photos of the First World War. As we grow our relations between Ireland and Belgium, the significance of the Saint Patrick’s Day Parade in the EU Capital and the need to support it becomes more apparent. Most funding sources in Ireland and Belgium require that we have “own funds” to be eligible for funding and this is where you can play your part to make our fundraising successful. The Parade assembles 13h00 on Sunday, 16th of March. It starts at the statue of ‘Le Chien Vert’ in the corner of Parc Cinquantenaire/Jubelpark. It is a multicultural opportunity to bring individuals, families and community organisations together at one big event, to get to know new Irish people and to make new friends and bridge the cultural divide with other communities. Participation is free and it makes a lovely afternoon family outing.

Every one is invited to “Wear the Green”, “Walk in the Parade”
&
Be “Irish for the Day”.

Donations can be made in two ways:
by Bank transfer to the IEAI Bankaccount by using these details:
Account name IEAI: Bank Crelan – Agentschap Jubelpark / Parc 50Naire, Avenue d´ Auderghem 59A,1040 Brussels.
IBAN BE[masked]
BIC SPAABE22

by Credit card: via Paypal by using: [masked] or click on this link http://irish-in-europe.eu/site/index.php/support-us/ all persons who make contribution to the parade financial or otherwise are listed on the Roll of Honour Sections of the Parade Web site.
www.brussels-st-patricks-day-parade.be For Parade Events: Visit our Irish in Europe events site - http://www.meetup.com/Irish-in-Europe

Thank you for reading this and thanks in advance for whatever contribution you decide to make.
Denis J. Buckley
President
Brussels Saint Patrick’s Day Parade of the Nations and Regions Committee

description: The Irish Theatre Group from Brussels will be hosting an evening of Irish culture in Kraainem this Sunday, the 16th of March, to celebrate St Patrick's Day. Tickets cost €10 and the evening will be held in GC de Lijsterbes. There will be extracts from famous Irish plays (The Importance of Being Earnest, Dancing at Lughnasa, The Matchmaker), poems, songs and music, as well as an ode to James Joyce and the centenary of World War I. The night has a great balance between theatre performances and live Irish traditional music. If ever you wanted to ring in St. Patrick’s Day in style, this is the place to be! For more information and to book tickets , please see the Irish Theatre Group's website - http://irishtheatrebrussels.com/next-production/sunday-march-16th-theatre-night/
name: Brussels Irish Theatre Group - Cultural Evening

description:
In Celebration of St.Patricks Day we've put together a host of Irish Comedians joined by the Award Winning Star of Irish TV and Radio, John Colleary. With : Musical Comedy by Youtube sensation David Duff and direct from the London Circuit, Mike Mc Mahon. And your MC for the evening is Belgiums very own Irish Comedian, David Hayden.

So put your best green dresses and shirts on, find a shamrock or a leprechaun for good luck and join us to savor good beer and food while enjoying the best humor from the Emerald Isle.

Ah sure come down. It'll be right Craic .. !!
