description:
We will visit the Celtic Weekend in Geluwe (Wervik) near Kortrijk, see link.
(Stokstraat 4, 8940 Wervik)


As public transport to the farm is difficult, the IEAI will offer a shuttle service (4 spaces available) to the Farm at 12pm from the railway station of Kortrijk and will drop you off again at that point at 7pm. 

There is a direct train from Brussels Central to Kortrijk, as you can see from this image. Or you can drive yourself (via E40, E17)


The traintrip will take you through the Vlaamse Ardennen (the locations made famous by the Tour of Flanders).


From there it's a small drive to the festival with my small blue van (15'-20').


A dayticket to the festival is €10. As I need to transfer the money to the organiser to register, please pay in advance. I will be in Brussels for Saint-Patrick's Day events. Anyone who RSVPs the event will receive a message with my bankdetails for easy payment.


The program is as follows:

12am: drive from the pickup point in Kortrijk to Geluwe. (1h drive)


2pm: (Irish) coffee / tea / cupcakes & bakery

3pm: Daithi Rua

4pm: Malahide


5pm: Uilléann Harp


6pm: return back to pickup point in Kortrijk.

There are trains to Brussels every hour.
name: Celtic Night Geluwe

description:
Please note  while the exhibition is open for viewing for Thursday evening 3rd. April,the vernissage will be on Monday 7 April at 7pm. See separate meet up event for this.


             “Bringing Brussels and Ireland closer together in Europe”

                    Limerick Meets Brussels - Brussels Meets Sligo

“Celebrating Limerick as City of Culture and Sligo as European Town of Sport


  Sligo and Limerick  to be showcased  in the Heart of Europe

    “Bringing Brussels and Ireland closer together in Europe”

             Limerick Meets Brussels - Brussels Meets Sligo

“Celebrating Limerick as City of Culture and Sligo as European Town of Sport

Sligo has been selected by the Irish in Europe Association as the town in Ireland under the ´Brussels Irish Village Project´ to be actively promoted in Europe as a holiday destination from March 17, 2014 to March 16, 2015.

The Saint Patrick’s Day Parade Committee of the Irish in Europe Association each year since 2009 designates in the Schuman Area of the EU Quarter in Brussels an Area to be known as the ´Irish Village´ to be named after a town in Ireland with cultural, trade or heritage significance and on a rotational basis.

The Irish Village which is named after a town on a rotational basis, whose purpose is to promote Irish and Irish Diaspora culture, hosts many Irish cultural activities during the annual Irish in Europe Féile. The Parade Committee shortlist a number of towns in Ireland for the twinning project before their final selection. The chosen town in the Irish Village Area is then extensively promoted over a year long period in Brussels, Belgium and across Europe.

This year Sligo town is chosen because of its outstanding achievements and accolades it received in Ireland to include the most recent:

European Town of Sport

The nomination of Sligo  will not only help the town and its county hinterland to attract more visitors but serve as an anchor gate-way town to the entire West of Ireland and help create a greater awareness of the region and grow marketing opportunities to generate more tourist numbers to justify additional direct flights from Continental Europe to Knock Airport. 

The first Irish Village in 2009 was named for Kilkenny in 2009, Derry in 2010.  Dalkey and Dún Laoghaire in 2011, Cork in 2012 and Westport presently hold the title.  

The project’s overall objective of the Irish Village project is to continuously promote Ireland as an attractive place in which to live, work and holiday in.

Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Program

The Irish in Europe Association as part of its cultural exchange program  have developed a culture promotional model of art and photo exhibitions to include the dissimulation of Irish Tourist information for the island of  island .  In the meantime exhibitions of  Brussels are on tour in Ireland as part of the program. See recent review of Exhibitions at Cork Vision Centre.  http://www.corkvisioncentre.com/corkvision2/Main/LikeATreeArt.htm         The  Brussels 'Like a Tree' Exhibition was launched at the Cork County Library at the County Hall in Cork  as part of  Ireland's National Tree Week.   


The Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Exhibition Curators in Ireland and Belgium   are "The Gallery Kinsale"  thegallerykinsale.com . Ken Buckley  of  "The Gallery Kinsale"  and Cultural Ambassador for the Irish in Europe Association in Ireland explains the Irish Cultural Exchange Program. https://soundcloud.com/roos-demol/interview-with-ken-buckley-of

 Each year the Irish in Europe select at least two Irish regions to promote in Europe.


This year Limerick City of Culture and Sligo European Town of Sport have been selected for the photo exhibition.

Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition at Halles Saint Gery. http://www.hallessaintgery.be/

The second annual Irish in Europe Art and Photo Exhibition will  open for viewing  on at Halles Saint Gery Cultural Centre in  Brussels  on April 3 and run until April  28 .

It will include exhibits from Limerick City of Culture and Sligo European Town of Sport with the aim to have additional mini exhibits including First World War.

The exhibition will be titled:

“Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition “Limerick meets Brussels –Brussels meets Sligo”

Irish in Europe Volunteers from different nationalities  will  be distributing tourist and cultural information in six languages promoting the island of  Ireland as a holiday destination including the flights from Brussels to Cork and Dublin.

Our  information stand will also  include  regional cultural and tourist information from Limerick and Sligo  together with a <a>Craftbay Marketplace</a> craft and design info portal of the craft and design outlets, design workshops  in Limerick  and Sligo  demonstrating  how the latest  innovations are  imbedded in Irish Art, Culture and Heritage.

Admission is Free. Open every day from 10am to 6pm. Late night opening on Thursday.


If you would like to help with this exhibition in anyway, man info stands etc please contact us at [masked]

See review of Review of the art element of 2013  Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition.You'll find the video by clicking on the link below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qjOfAGentq0

description:
Please note while the Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition is open to the public from Thursday evening 3 April, the official opening/ vernissage will take place on Monday 7th. April at 19.00...

Limerick meets Brussels – Brussels meets Sligo

Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition

Art

3 April – 28 April 2014

Halles Saint-Géry

Place Saint- Géry 1, 1000 Brussels, Belgium

www.thegallerykinsale.com

http://www.meetup.com/Irish-in-Europe 

Curated by Catherine McEntee

For the second consecutive year, The Gallery Kinsale along with the Irish in Europe Association (International) aisbl (IEAI) is delighted to announce an exhibition of Irish Art in Brussels. A fully voluntary initiative, a selection of art works will be brought from counties Limerick and Sligo. The exhibition will take place in the cultural centre of Brussels, in Halles Saint Géry, with the aim of show-casing contemporary Irish Art in Belgium. The show which will run from 3rd – 28th April 2014 includes photography, prints, Irish archive First World War photos and a selection of images courtesy of Fáilte Ireland and information on Irish Crafts through Craftbay. Limerick and Sligo have specially been chosen for representation this year as, Limerick is the City of Culture 2014 and Sligo is European Town Sport for 2014.

   The Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition -Limerick meets Brussels – Brussels meets Sligo, aims to bring Ireland and Belgium closer together in Europe, highlighting the already strong links and introducing new ones.

  Following the success of last year’s initiative in Halles Saint Géry and Galerie Anspach, during the year of the Irish Presidency of  the  European Union Council of Ministers, this year’s exhibition and information stand manned by volunteers hopes to entice exhibition visitors to discover what Ireland holds as a holiday destination and build on important relationships that are growing between the two countries, with the direct flights from Brussels to Cork being emphasised with Aer Lingus in addition to the existing Ryan Air/Aer Lingus routes. The exhibition also contributes to generating markets for new direct flights from Belgium, for Shannon and Knock to service the Wild Atlantic Way.

The project will strive to highlight the export of Irish Art and Crafts for the mutual focus on cultural and business benefits between the two countries. Information will be continuously at hand with art experts offering guidance for the duration of the show.

“We are excited and proud for the second year to have the opportunity to showcase a selection of high quality Irish art in the cultural centre of Brussels. We will be taking this opportunity to promote Ireland as a holiday destination, through a fantastic selection of photographs and prints that represent counties Limerick and Sligo.” (Catherine McEntee, exhibition curator)

This year’s participants include Annmarie Bourke, Conor Doherty, Godfrey Graham, Gavin Hogg and Ciaran McHugh, as well as a selection of images courtesy of Fáilte Ireland and information from Craft Bay on Irish Craft. 

The Brussels Exhibition is part of the ongoing Irish in Europe cultural exchange programme launched in Ireland and Belgium in 2013 by the Brussels-based Irish in Europe Association. The main function of the IEAI is to help the world-wide Irish Diaspora living and working in Europe and promote Irish culture, community-building and micro integration through a network of Chapters in Europe. To reinforce the success of the cultural exchange program in Belgium and Ireland, the Brussels ‘Like a Tree’ Exhibition will be opened at Mallow Town Library by Councillor Noel O’ Connor, Mayor of Cork County Council in Ireland on 3 April – the same date as the opening of the Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition at Halles Saint Géry in Brussels.

END

Notes on Exhibition Curator Catherine McEntee

Catherine McEntee is an independent curator, event manager and writer from Ireland, based in Brussels. Catherine has a degree in History of Art and English and a Masters in Modern and Contemporary Art.

Catherine previously worked in Lismore Castle Arts for three years as Education Officer and in the Lewis Glucksman Gallery for over three years as Head of Visitor Experience organising one of Irelands leading Craft Fairs and coordinating numerous events and cultural activities.

Notes on The Gallery Kinsale:

  The Gallery Kinsale is owned and managed in one of the most picturesque, popular and fashionable resorts of the sunny south-west coast of Ireland by Ken Buckley who is also the premier art agent in  Munster - Ireland's largest Province.

  Ken has organised some of the biggest exhibitions in his home city of Cork and lasts year’s exhibition in Halles Saint Géry and Galerie Anspach. These larger exhibitions were curated at Cork Vision Centre, Cork’s Leading visitor and exhibition centre as well as a multitude of exhibitions in his own Galleries and other venues around the country.

Ken is an ambassador for the Cork Business Chamber, Cultural Ambassador for the Irish in Europe Association in Ireland & is also on the Cork Jazz Festival Committee along with various charitable events he coordinates through the Gallery calendar year.

description:
Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition

                                  Limerick Meets Brussels - Brussels Meets Sligo

  “Celebrating Limerick as City of Culture and Sligo as European Town of Sport

    “Bringing Brussels and Ireland closer together in Europe”


                                                                3 April – 28 April 2014

                                                                 Halles Saint-Géry

                                              Place Saint- Géry 1, 1000 Brussels

        Admission is Free. Open every day from 10am to 6pm

Curated by Catherine McEntee:

For the second consecutive year, The Gallery Kinsale along with the Irish in Europe Association (International) aisbl (IEAI) is delighted to announce an exhibition of Irish Art in Brussels. A fully voluntary initiative, a selection of art works will be brought from counties Limerick and Sligo. The exhibition takes place in the cultural centre of Brussels, in Halles Saint Géry, with the aim of show-casing contemporary Irish Art in Belgium. The show  runs from 3rd – 28th April 2014 includes photography, prints, Irish archive First World War photos and a selection of images courtesy of Fáilte Ireland and information on Irish Crafts through Craftbay. Limerick and Sligo have specially been chosen for representation this year as, Limerick is the City of Culture 2014 and Sligo is European Town Sport for 2014.

  The Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition -Limerick meets Brussels – Brussels meets Sligo, aims to bring Ireland and Belgium closer together in Europe, highlighting the already strong links and introducing new ones.

  Following the success of last year’s initiative in Halles Saint Géry and Galerie Anspach, during the year of the Irish Presidency of  the  European Union Council of Ministers, this year’s exhibition and information stand manned by volunteers hopes to entice exhibition visitors to discover what Ireland holds as a holiday destination and build on important relationships that are growing between the two countries, with the direct flights from Brussels to Cork being emphasised with Aer Lingus in addition to the existing Ryan Air/Aer Lingus routes. The exhibition also contributes to generating markets for new direct flights from Belgium, for Shannon and Knock to service the Wild Atlantic Way.

The project will strive to highlight the export of Irish Art and Crafts for the mutual focus on cultural and business benefits between the two countries. Information will be continuously at hand with art experts offering guidance for the duration of the show.

“We are excited and proud for the second year to have the opportunity to showcase a selection of high quality Irish art in the cultural centre of Brussels. We will be taking this opportunity to promote Ireland as a holiday destination, through a fantastic selection of photographs and prints that represent counties Limerick and Sligo.” (Catherine McEntee, exhibition curator)

This year’s participants include Annmarie Bourke, Conor Doherty, Godfrey Graham, Gavin Hogg and Ciaran McHugh, as well as a selection of images courtesy of Fáilte Ireland and information from Craft Bay on Irish Craft. 

The Brussels Exhibition is part of the ongoing Irish in Europe cultural exchange programme launched in Ireland and Belgium in 2013 by the Brussels-based Irish in Europe Association. The main function of the IEAI is to help the world-wide Irish Diaspora living and working in Europe and promote Irish culture, community-building and micro integration through a network of Chapters in Europe. To reinforce the success of the cultural exchange program in Belgium and Ireland, the Brussels ‘Like a Tree’ Exhibition opened at Mallow Town Library by Councillor Noel O’ Connor, Mayor of Cork County Council in Ireland on 3 April – the same date as the opening of the Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition at Halles Saint Géry in Brussels.

Curator: Catherine McEntee

Catherine McEntee is an independent curator, event manager and writer from Ireland, based in Brussels. Catherine has a degree in History of Art and English and a Masters in Modern and Contemporary Art.

Catherine previously worked in Lismore Castle Arts for three years as Education Officer and in the Lewis Glucksman Gallery for over three years as Head of Visitor Experience organising one of Irelands leading Craft Fairs and coordinating numerous events and cultural activities.

The Gallery Kinsale:

  The Gallery Kinsale is owned and managed in one of the most picturesque, popular and fashionable resorts of the sunny south-west coast of Ireland by Ken Buckley who is also the premier art agent in  Munster - Ireland's largest Province.

  Ken has organised some of the biggest exhibitions in his home city of Cork and lasts year’s exhibition in Halles Saint Géry and Galerie Anspach. These larger exhibitions were curated at Cork Vision Centre, Cork’s Leading visitor and exhibition centre as well as a multitude of exhibitions in his own Galleries and other venues around the country.

Ken is an ambassador for the Cork Business Chamber, Cultural Ambassador for the Irish in Europe Association in Ireland & is also on the Cork Jazz Festival Committee along with various charitable events he coordinates through the Gallery calendar year.

Email: [masked]

  www.thegallerykinsale.com

http://www.meetup.com/Irish-in-Europe


It is possible to arrange for press interviews with the curator. For further discussion on the exhibition, press images or more detailed information, please contact  Catherine McEntee at: [masked]

For more info on the Irish in Europe Association/Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Program...Contact Denis J. Buckley at [masked] 

If you would like to volunteer for stand duties  at exhibition or help with English to Dutch and French translations,please write to: </a> [masked] .


More Information:


Sligo has been selected by the Irish in Europe Association as the town in Ireland under the ´Brussels Irish Village Project´ to be actively promoted in Europe as a holiday destination from March 17, 2014 to March 16, 2015.

The Saint Patrick’s Day Parade Committee of the Irish in Europe Association each year since 2009 designates in the Schuman Area of the EU Quarter in Brussels an Area to be known as the ´Irish Village´ to be named after a town in Ireland with cultural, trade or heritage significance and on a rotational basis.

The Irish Village which is named after a town on a rotational basis, whose purpose is to promote Irish and Irish Diaspora culture, hosts many Irish cultural activities during the annual Irish in Europe Féile. The Parade Committee shortlist a number of towns in Ireland for the twinning project before their final selection. The chosen town in the Irish Village Area is then extensively promoted over a year long period in Brussels, Belgium and across Europe.

This year Sligo town is chosen because of its outstanding achievements and accolades it received in Ireland to include the most recent:

European Town of Sport

The nomination of Sligo  will not only help the town and its county hinterland to attract more visitors but serve as an anchor gate-way town to the entire West of Ireland and help create a greater awareness of the region and grow marketing opportunities to generate more tourist numbers to justify additional direct flights from Continental Europe to Knock Airport. 

The first Irish Village in 2009 was named for Kilkenny in 2009, Derry in 2010.  Dalkey and Dún Laoghaire in 2011, Cork in 2012 and Westport in 2013.


The project’s overall objective of the Irish Village project is to continuously promote Ireland as an attractive place in which to live, work and holiday in.

Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Program

The Irish in Europe Association as part of its cultural exchange program  have developed a culture promotional model of art and photo exhibitions to include the dissimulation of Irish Tourist information for the island of  island .  In the meantime exhibitions of  Brussels are on tour in Ireland as part of the program. See recent review of Exhibitions at Cork Vision Centre.  <a href="http://www.corkvisioncentre.com/corkvision2/Main/LikeATreeArt.htm">http://www.corkvisioncentre.com/corkvision2/Main/LikeATreeArt.htm         The  Brussels 'Like a Tree' Exhibition was launched at the Cork County Library at the County Hall in Cork  as part of  Ireland's National Tree Week.   


The Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Exhibition Curators in Ireland and Belgium   are "The Gallery Kinsale"  thegallerykinsale.com . Ken Buckley  of  "The Gallery Kinsale"  and Cultural Ambassador for the Irish in Europe Association in Ireland explains the Irish Cultural Exchange Program. https://soundcloud.com/roos-demol/interview-with-ken-buckley-of

 Each year the Irish in Europe select at least two Irish regions to promote in Europe.


This year Limerick City of Culture and Sligo European Town of Sport have been selected for the photo exhibition.

Irish in Europe Art & Photo Exhibition at Halles Saint Gery. http://www.hallessaintgery.be/

Admission is Free. Open every day from 10am to 6pm.

description:
Concert Preview- Celebrating Europe in May at Gare du Luxembourg-Brussels - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9JszJCfwv6c&feature=youtu.be

 

Europe Day ‘Open Doors Day’ in Brussels, 17th of May 2014.Lunch Time Concert  - “Music of the “ European Nations & Regions”  Preview  played and arranged  by Dénes Dosztán.

www.denesdosztan.com  


Luxembourg Train Station / Gare Du Luxembourg (European Parliament Station)

Organised by Irish in Europe Association in association with European Parliament and hosted by Railway Stations of Belgium / SNCB/NMBS.
Het Station leeft! www.hetstation.be
La vie entre en Gare! www.lagare.be

'Music of the European Nations & Regions Concert with Dénes Dosztán on piano.
1 p.m. – 3 p.m “Open Day” Lunch Time Concert.

This concert organised and commissioned by the Irish in Europe Association (International) aisbl in 2013 to mark the Irish EU Presidency of the Council of Ministers January 2013 to June 2013 and the 40 years of Ireland’s Membership of the European Union 1973 – 2013. It also recognises the entry of Croatia as the 28th Member State of EU. It is an appropriate arrangement of music on the piano with signature tunes of Member States that helps connect all citizens to the musical heritage and traditions of the Nations and Regions of the European Union. The concert is on tour in Europe as part of the on-going Irish in Europe Cultural Exchange Program. It will be followed by a Cork Jazz Festival Club of Brussels session with rag time & Irish melodies with Resident Artiste Dénes Dosztán on piano. Everyone welcome  – admission free.

‘Music of the European Nations and Regions’ is one of our ongoing collaborations with Dénes Dosztán that started with his performance at the EU Hungarian Presidency–Irish Cultural Fusion event in 2011 at the Aloft Brussels Schuman and continued with the Bloomsday Irish-Hungarian evenings in Brussels, his residency of the Cork Jazz Festival Club of Brussels and the commissioning of Ragtime & Jazz with Irish Melodies CD for the Parade celebrations in 2012.


Dénes Dosztán (b. 1984) received a diploma of eminence as violinist and violin teacher in 2008 at the Faculty of Music of the University of Debrecen, Hungary. In 2011 he finished his studies as a master in music - violin performance at the Royal Conservatory of Brussels. He regularly performs as a pianist, as well, classical music, Irish melodies, ragtime and early jazz, including solo or in ensemble. Apart from Serbia and Hungary, Dénes has performed at concerts in Austria, Belgium, Britain, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Switzerland and Ireland. Since 2013 Dénes Dosztán has been working as the resident artist of the Cork Jazz Festival Club of Brussels under the patronage of the Irish in Europe Association. Website: www.denesdosztan.com


________________________

,,I met Dénes Dosztán years ago in Hungary and I have a great souvenir about meeting him. His personality was very strong and charming. I had a wonderful feeling about this young artist. I recently heard his piano playing and I have to say that I am amazed about the clarity and precision of his technique. But the most important part for me is that he touches my soul in his rendition of the slower tunes. I highly recommend this young musician to your attention."
Mimi Blais, pianist, „Queen of Ragtime” (Quebec, Canada)

,,Dénes is not only a versatile, excellent artist – who can adapt himself to his environment with an unbelievable artistical sense in order to exploit the maximum of his vocation –, but has been my true friend since 10 years, in whom I can discover myself." Nándor Fekete, concert organist


,,Energy, authenticity, sensibility and versatility are the keywords that describe the young and talented Dénes Dosztán."
Benjamin Intartaglia, pianist, composer, organist (Paris, France)

description:
Brussels Jazz Marathon comes to the Irish Village Quarter -23-25 May


On[masked] may, You invite you to a weekend under the sign of JAZZ!
During the Brussels Jazz Marathon, Brussels is more than ever the capital of jazz!

Rendez-vous at Grand Place, the Sablon Square, the St-Catherine Square, Fernand Cock Square, and NEW this year, in the Irish Village Quarter (Metro Schuman Area) where you can enjoy performances in Irish Pubs and bars until the end of the night.
Jazz, blues, funk, world: take your choice! There are all sorts of sounds and vibes for even the most discerning tastes. Add FREE admission for everyone, a special matinee for kids, free up- and downtown shuttles and a swinging, friendly atmosphere all over the city... and you will understand that this event is an absolute must!

And we are already looking forward to the festive edition of 2015. Next year we celebrate the 20th edition!

For 19 years, the weekend of the Brussels Jazz Marathon is a unique opportunity to release the jazz enthusiast in you!

The Irish Votes for the local and By-elections will be counted on Saturday but the European Election boxes are opened on the SUNDAY. Under EU elections rules,no count can be announced in any country until all the voting is finished in every Member State.

Discover who govern Europe. Join us on May 25 for a special evening .

Place du Luxembourg from  19.00h
  Parlamentarium from  20h[masked]


On 25 May , Participate in a unique evening dedicated to European elections :

• Follow live results


• Taste the flavors of Europe


• benefit from an extension of the Brussels Jazz Marathon


• share your opinions

An evening devoted to the results of the European elections.

Initial projections at European level will be made public at 22.00 h with  partial results announced continuously until midnight.

 It will be warm and unique opportunity to share your opinions with friends and lovers politics.

Place du Luxembourg will be THE place to be . Bars and cafes are open. You can live and on giant screens, follow what happens inside the European Parliament, against a backdrop of jazz music since the Brussels Jazz Marathon will be extended for one evening.

Lovers of good food will also have the pleasure of meeting the Irish chefs  and French Clodagh McKenna and Pierre Lefebvre  at the European Parliament ( former railway station ) and the Bureau Parlamentarium 20:30 to 21:30.

You will finally welcome ( e) Parlamentarium which held debates , panels and analyzes from 20:30 to midnight.


See you on May 25, place du Luxembourg for a special evening dedicated to European elections

description:
Bloomsday
Irish-Hungarian  Evening

 Mini BBQ from 7.00 in beer garden & at rear of Pub
  To be followed Music Recital
by Dénes Dosztán
on  piano  from circa  9.00pm

At the James Joyce Irish Pub


(First Irish Pub in Brussels & Celebrating 25 years in Brussels)
Date: Monday  June 16, 2014 from 7.00 to 23.30

Blooms Day on the 16th of June is celebrated as a holiday by scholars and fans of Ulysses, the novel by James Joyce. It was on this day that the events of the novel took place in Dublin in 1904.
Blooms Day is named after Leopold Bloom - a Hungarian, the middle-aged advertising salesman who is the protagonist of the famous book by Joyce, which was published in 1922.

Come along in the fashion of 1904 or in your own country traditional costume (1904 Football Gear?)if you wish.


There will be some readings from Ulysses with a special recital by Dénes Dosztán (Violinist, Pianist and Teacher www.denesdosztan.com ) of Irish Melodies and Hungarian music that was played in Hungary and Ireland in 1904.

"Joyce was a musician and a wordman, and Ulysses, an encyclopaedia of human achievement as well as a novel, ignores the visual arts because of a temperamental lacuna"

To celebrate the 110 anniversary of the first Blooms Day, the concert pre-launch CD "The Music of Bloom " commissioned by the Irish in Europe Association will be on sale.

‘The Music of Bloom’ an Irish in Europe cultural fusion project is a musical arrangement by Dénes Dosztán on violin and Klára Bábel on harp that commemorates the 110 nth.  anniversary of the first Bloomsday and celebrates the life of Joyce. It is part of an ongoing collaboration of the Irish-Hungarian relationship in Brussels that has grown out of the Irish-Hungarian Presidency event at the Aloft Brussels Schuman hotel in 2011 and the annual Brussels flagship event-‘Bloomsday Irish–Hungarian evening’

Meet and circulate  first at Beer Garden & rear of pub for drinks & BBQ
 Music recital from 9pm after the Germany V Portugal  Football Match.


All are welcome! Admission free

Mini BBQ Choice of Burger at 5 euro or Hotdog at 3.50 euro to:

[masked]

description:
Two Poets, One War Cemetery, One Destiny...


                        Two Poets, One War Cemetery, One Destiny...

                                     Hedd Wyn

Francis Ledwidge

We  have our  4th.annual Commemoration  to celebrate the life of Francis Ledwidge. An Irish poet , killed in action during World War I.

We also join up with  CYMDEITHAS GYMREIG BRWSEL – WELSH SOCIETY OF BRUSSELS to commemorate the life of Ellis Humphrey Evans (‘Hedd Wyn’),  a Welsh poet, killed in action during World War I, on the same day, during the same battle, in the same sector as Francis Ledwidge.

The joint Irish-Welsh commemoration event takes place for the first time at by kind courtesy of Muntpunt- the newly reopened Dutch language  community library in the heart of Brussels:(Metro De Brouckère).


The event will include audio visual presentations, guest lecture, poetry readings and open forum. Also on display will the Irish in Europe on Tour Mini WW1 Photo Exhibition in addition to Welsh photos and memorabilia.

Guest Lecture by Mr. Lieven Dehandschutter, author of book in three languages (Dutch,English and Welsh) on  the life and work of Hedd Wyn. He is Burgemeester of Sint-Niklaas in the province of East Flanders. The city is known for having the largest market square in Belgium.

Admission Free-Everyone Welcome

Literature Salon (access through the Grand Café)


Muntpunt Library

Munt 6


1000 Brussels

Followed by social & network drink Muntpunt Grand Café


Francis Edward Ledwidge

was an Irish war poet from County Meath. Sometimes known as the "poet of the blackbirds", The Poetry of Ledwidge is an integral part of the Treasury of Irish Verse.

Francis Ledwidge was born on August 19 ,1887 at Slane, County Meath, Ireland, into a large and poverty-stricken family.

Within a week of the outbreak of WW1, he joined the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers in Dublin.

In 1915 he saw action at Suvla Bay in Turkey. Having survived Gallipoli , he was dismayed by the news of the Easter Rising and was court-martialled and demoted for overstaying his home leave and being drunk in uniform.

 On 31 July 1917, a group from Ledwidge's battalion of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers were road-laying near Pilkem Ridge in preparation for an assault during the Third Battle of Ypres, near the village of Boezinge, northwest of Ieper (Ypres). While Ledwidge was drinking tea in a mud hole with his comrades, a shell exploded alongside, killing the poet and five others. A chaplain who knew him, Father Devas, arrived soon after, and recorded "Ledwidge killed, blown to bits."     In due course he was laid to rest in the Artillery Wood CWGC Cemetery at Boezinge in Belgium.
  “He shall not hear the bittern cry
In the wild sky, where he is lain,
Nor voices of the sweeter birds
Above the wailing of the rain.
  One of three verses in his ‘Lament for Thomas MacDonagh’, one the executed leaders of the Irish rebellion at Easter, 1916.

When he wrote these lines he unwittingly composed his own enduring epitaph.

The Wife of Llew

A poem for Wales by Francis Ledwidge...

June

A poem for summer by Francis Ledwidge...


A Robin on a Broken Tree


Just four poignant lines of longing for home by Francis Ledwidge


The poems Ledwidge wrote on active service revealed his pride at being a soldier, as he believed, in the service of Ireland. He wondered whether he would find a soldier's death. The dead were buried at Carrefour de Rose, and later re-interred in the nearby Artillery Wood Military Cemetery, Boezinge, (where the Welsh poet Hedd Wyn, killed on the same day, is also buried). A stone tablet commemorates him in the Island of Ireland Peace Park, Messines, Belgium. His work as “peasant poet” and “soldier poet”, once a standard part of the Irish school curriculum, faded from view for many decades of the 20th century. Its intensity, coupled with a revived interest in his period, has restored it to life.

The reading of his poem "Ireland" forms part of the wreath laying ceremony for annual Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday Commemoration. For the first ceremony in 2011, the poem was recited by Mary Jo Mullarkey.

Ellis Humphrey Evans (‘Hedd Wyn’)
  A Welsh poet, killed in action during World War I, on the same day, during the same battle, in the same sector as Francis Ledwidge.
  Private of the 15th Royal Welsh Fusiliers. A Welsh national hero, having won six Bardic Chairs.  He was the subject of the 1992 film, Hedd Wyn,, nominated for a Foreign‑Language Film Oscar.

He was born on January 13, 1887 near the village of Trawsfynydd, Wales. He was killed during an assault on the German lines at Pilkem Ridge on July 31, 1917. In due course he was laid to rest in the Artillery Wood CWGC Cemetery at Boezinge in Belgium.
  The last of the three verses of his most famous poem, Rhyfel (‘War’):

“The old harps that were played in a time of joys
Hang from the branches of that willow wood,
The wind fills up with the screams of boys,
And the falling rain with their blood.”

Every one is welcome along to this poetry evening  of readings  to learn more about these poets. Admission Free.

Please visit www.francisledwidge.com and be sure to visit while in Ireland the Francis Ledwidge Museum at Janesville,Slane,County Meath.

More information will be posted on program closer to event.


[masked]


Twee dichters,

Eén oorlogskerkhof, Eén lot...

Gezamelijke Iers-Welse Grote Oorlogsherdenking  

  Francis Ledwidge  Hedd Wyn

Franc­is Ledwidge & Hedd Wyn Poetry Evening Donderdagavond 31 juli, 2014 vanaf 19:00 uur

Gratis toegang – iedereen welkom!

Na afloop kan er worden geborreld in Grand Café Muntpunt

The Irish in Europe Association (International) IVZW in samenwerking met de Welsh Society of Brussels en Bibliotheek Muntpunt herdenken  en vieren het leven van de Ierse dichter Francis Ledwidge en de Welshe dichter Ellis Humphrey Evans (‘Hedd Wyn’). Beide kwamen om in de Grote Oorlog, op dezelfde dag en in dezelfde slag, ze zijn ook op dezelfde plek begraven.

Bibliotheek Muntpunt
Literaire Salon
Munt 6, 1000 Brussel(Toegang via het Grand Café)

WO1 foto expositie, muziek en filmbeelden, lezing, gedichten en discussie.

  Gast lezing door Lieven Dehandschutter, burgemeester van Sint-Niklaas. Hij is de schrijver van een drietalig (Nederlands, Engels en Wels) boek over het leven en werk van Hedd Wyn.

  www.meetup.com/Irish-in-Europe  [masked]

description:
First World War 1 Commemoration at Mayo Peace Park –Castlebar, Ireland.

The Mayo Peace Park committee & Mayo County Council have agreed to host a special "Mayo Commemoration Day" at the Mayo Peace Park on Sunday the 3rd of August 2014. The event will start at 2.30pm. This will mark the 100th anniversary of world war one in county Mayo. We have already hosted a number of events this year.
It will be an all embracing ceremony, however the main focus will be on the 100th anniversary of world war one and on those from Ireland and from County Mayo who served & died in it.
It will be a major ecumenical event, with a significant clerical involvement. All the local Mayo area Bishops and clergy are invited .
We will have music & song for a joyful ceremony, we have a choir as well as the town band and some serious singers . We will be inviting all the officials and councillors as well as the local MEP´s and T.D's. ( no they wont all be speaking ).
We are currently in the process of finding out, if "An Taoiseach" will be able to attend the event and perhaps some other serious politician to represent the government.

Mr Kevin Myers the well known Journalist & Columnist is the invited guest speaker on the day.

August Weekend
There will be a localised world war exibition of memorabilia running in the County Library all week.

On Friday the 1st of August,
We have four events
4.30pm, Launch of the exibition in the library by Dr Myles Dungan.

5pm a public lecture by Dr Ciaran Wallace. : Women & Children First , The Home Front During World War One.

6pm a public lecture by Dr Myles Dungan : Lions, Donkeys & Paddies The Irish Experience of the Great War. 8.30pm ; We have the return of the wonderful Brendan McQuaile play "March Away My Brothers" in the Linenhall Theatre. Booking will be essential.

Saturday 2nd of August. Visitors Open Day at the Mayo Peace Park. Social Evening for our Visitors

Sunday the 3rd of August. Mayo Commemoration Day, World War One Commemoration Ceremony. All are welcome

Michael Feeney MBE (2013 Parade Grand Marshal of Brussels Saint Patrick’s Day Parade of the Nations & Regions)
Secretary, Mayo Peace Park.
[masked] - website; www.mayopeacepark.ie Nearest Airport Knock. Train & Bus Service from Dublin
name: First World War Commemoration at Mayo Peace Park–Castlebar, Ireland

description:
Following  the wonderful success of our Francis Ledwidge/Hedd Wyn commemoration event at the Muntpunt Library, we are going back there  for our traditional 'Crossing Borders on the Terrace' activity at the terrace of the Muntpunt Grand Cafe . Entrance to the Munt Grand Cafe is via the Muntpunt library up to 8pm or directly  at any time onto the terrace from Leopold Street at rear of library. 

Crossing Borders on the Terrace is part of “Village Integration Project” organised by the IEAI The Irish meet other  cultures on the   Terrace at the


Muntpunt Grand Café/Bar, (Metro De Brouckère -3 minutes walk).


Leopoldstraat 6 rue Léopold, 1000 Brussels, Belgium

Each culture shares information with other nationalities about their culture, holiday and home hunting tips and also on topics such as living and working in Brussels as they laze and chat in the sunshine over a beer,wine or coffee. Food Served. Come along and meet the different nationalities each week. Guests can come and go at any time and stay longer if they wish. Admission Free……..and please let all your friends  know who will be in Brussels.
- All nationalities are Welcome!  Admission Free.

PS If it rains-we will meet inside the café and not on the terrace

Muntpunt-the newly reopened Dutch language community library in the heart of Brussels.
 English language brochures about Muntpunt will be available, Some interesting statistics about Muntpunt: 8000 m², [masked] items (about 60k CDs), a superb collection of books about Brussels. No other public library in Brussels can match English language collection. They also have a very interesting multilingual collection of books translated from Dutch and the biggest collection of Dutch language courses you can find anywhere in Belgium. More details of the facilities of Muntpunt and its architectural history  will be posted in coming days.


If you want to have an informal tour of the library come at 6.30 pm but let us know directly at [masked].  A more formal tour will be organised as soon as we are sure that will have sufficient persons interested to justify a longer and  detailed tour provided by library staff.

The Irish in Europe Association are forming a Library advisory committee  to provide feedback to the Muntpunt management and to make any suggestions on books or other materials that could be stocked in the library. If you would like to join this committee,please let us know.

To join the library costs just 10 euro a year and that includes free use of the internet or WiFi system when you bring your own laptop or pad along. You can learn more about facilities during the Meetup.
name: Crossing Borders on the Terrace at Muntpunt Grand Café

description:
We have gone for a different" back to work party" this year,instead of having our traditional BBQ, we have gone for a Piazza Party on the terrace. If it rains,we can all move in doors so easy. But looks like we are going to have a mini Indian Summer for next few days with temperatures from 23 degrees!!! So come along and enjoy the last of the Summer Wine!!! We have organised a special piazza offer -----any piazza on the menu for just 10 euro.

Each culture shares information with other nationalities about their culture, holiday and home hunting tips and also on topics such as living and working in Brussels as they laze and chat in the sunshine over a beer,wine or coffee.  Other Food on the menu is also served to suit all tastes. Come along and meet the different nationalities. Guests can come and go at any time and stay longer if they wish.……..And please let all your friends and work colleagues you  know who will be in Brussels....and a special welcome to Newcomers !!!!!
- All nationalities are Welcome!  Admission Free.


Everyone welcome -Admission Free and feel free to inform your friends and work colleagues.
name: Back to Work Piazza Party on the Terrace

description:
Tickets  are 12 euros for Adults. 8 euros for Children.

Reservation essential to guarantee seat. Both bands generate a lot of interest, and also Shantalla  have a loyal fan base and don't play that often

 Reserve to shantallabothan[at]gmail.com.

On receipt of your reservation and on confirmation of seats are available, you will be provided with bank account details. Receipt of payment secures tickets which will be issued at the door on the night.

It promises to be a special evening!!!!

Shantalla and Bothan. Although they are Brussels based, Shantalla are known internationally - they first came to people's attention in 1999, broke up in 2005 and then reformed about four years ago. You can find out more about them on their website shantallamusic.com. They are particularly well known for their lively and virtuoso performances of jigs and reels.

Bothan are also Brussels based, and their music is more ballad-centred, built around the matching voices of Jane McBride (Ireland) and Elise Docherty (Scotland). You can find more information about them on their website bothancelticfolkgroup.com

Getting there by public transport:

Take the Metro to Stockel: Then take  Tram 39 Direction Baneik across road from main metro exit.
Or take the 39 Tram from Montgomery Direction Baneik.

You get out at Tram Stop “ Beek/Ruisseau, third last stop on the line.
It is about 5 to 7 minutes  Walk from Tram Stop to De Kam.

Metro Journey from Schuman to Stockel is circa 17 minutes . 

Tram from Stockel to Beek/ Russeau is circa 7 minutes


Tram from Mongomery to Beek/ Russeau is circa 25 minutes.

The tram frequency is normally every 20 minutes.

Meetup will take place at the bar in advance of the concert. It is a lovely court yard type cultural centre.  You may purchase the special beer brewed for De Kam There are snack options and a choice or warm and cold drinks.


Tickets  are 12 euros for Adults. 8 euros for Children.

Reservation essential to guarantee seat. Both bands generate a lot of interest, and also Shantalla  have a loyal fan base and don't play that often

 Reserve to shantallabothan[at]gmail.com.

On receipt of your reservation and on confirmation that seats are available, you will be provided with bank account details. Receipt of payment secures tickets which will be issued at the door on the night.


De kam
Beekstraat 172
1970 Wezembeek-Oppem
name: Shantalla and Bothan in concert at De KAM

description:
Guinness Presents: Schuman Music Festival
The first and inaugural edition of the Schuman Festival will take place November 6th – 9th in the Schuman Area also known to many as the " Irish Village" area in Brussels, Belgium.
The four day festival, will bring together great music, the Schuman community and benefit BIG against breast cancer, an international non-profit organisation for academic breast cancer research groups from around the world.
The Old Oak, Kitty O’Shea’s, The Hairy Canary, The Funky Monkey, Coolock Café and the James Joyce Irish Pub will all be participating and hosting the four day festival. The best way to participate is to purchase a wristband from any of the participating pubs, proceeds of which will go directly to Big against Breast Cancer, as well as grant you a discount on all sponsored drinks in the pubs or sponsoring some of the fund raising activities through the website.

The festival will kick off with a pampering session in Kitty O’Shea’s, where Karen McHugh will take the stage on Thursday, November 6th at 18:00. The party continues a short walk away, in The Hairy Canary, where the band Little Things will perform for 'ladies night' from 20:30.

.Friday night 7 November , a folk-rock session with Mystery tramp will begin at 20:00 in the Funky Monkey, with a whiskey tasting taking place downstairs. The party continues across the street, in The James Joyce Irish Pub, where Daniel Johnson will begin his set at 22:00 and a few brave men will get their chests waxed in support of Big against Breast Cancer.
On Saturday 8 November evening, the main event will take place in The Old Oak, where the Pogues tribute band, A 1000 Sails will begin the show at 20:00. One of Ireland’s best singer/songwriters, John Spillane, will follow. There will be also many fundraising events the whole day through.
Sunday will bring the festival to a close in the Coolock Café. Jack O’Shea’s Irish butcher will host an autumn bbq from 16 and where we will be treated to the tunes of Daithi Rua

Grab some friends, and come enjoy the craic and the best that Schuman has to offer, all in aid of a great cause!
name: Guinness Presents: Schuman Music Festival (4 Days)

description:
4.th. Annual Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday.

The Irish in Europe Association (International) aisbl  in compliance with its aims and objectives remembers all Irish and the Irish Diaspora in all armies who died in all wars and conflicts. IEAI in particular remembers the 50,000 Irish who died and estimated 500,000 members of the Irish Diaspora in all Armies who participated during the liberation of Belgium in the first and second world wars.

Let those who come after us see to it that their names be not forgotten
Hence it will have its fourth Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday in Brussels on Saturday 8 November at 11.30 am. The IEAI will lay a wreath at the Anglo-Belgian War Memorial at Place Poelaert / Poelaertplein in front of Palais de Justice de Bruxelles and across from the Infantry Memorial of Brussels in memory of the Belgian foot soldiers who fought in World War I and II. (Metro or Tram Louise 3 minutes walk). The Anglo-Belgian War Memorial commemorates the heroic Belgian people who helped the Irish and British prisoners of war during World War I. Designed by the British sculptor Charles Sargeant Jagger [masked]), the monument was inaugurated in 1923. The composition, in Brainvilliers stone, features figures of Irish, British and Belgian soldiers. The sides are covered with reliefs representing scenes of Belgian common folk tending to wounded British soldiers. There is also a relief of an Irish harp. A plaster cast of the statues of soldiers can be seen at the Military Museum in Brussels. Following the laying of the wreath, a poem by Irish Poet Francis Ledwidge will be recited. He enlisted in the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers in 1914 and was killed in the battle of Ypres on the 31st July 1917. See www.francisledwidge.com . After the ceremony, guests shall proceed to Mac Sweeney's Irish Pub for warm refreshments at Jean Stasstraat, Brussels 1060 located to the right of Avenue Louise about 7 minutes walk from the memorial. On the way the group shall stop at the site of the former residence in exile of William Smith O Brien, one of the leaders of the Irish Rebellion of 1848 and direct descendent of King Brian Boru who was killed at the Battle of Clontarf in 1014. He also lived in Hungary where he advised the Hungarian Independence Movement. Every one is welcome to come along to the fourth annual Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday ceremony.
“Your Donation to help defray costs would be much appreciated“

Bank: Centea
Name account: IEAI
Account nr:[masked]
IBAN: BE[masked]
SWIFT/BIC-code: BIC SPAABE22

description:
4th. Annual Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday.

The Irish in Europe Association (International) AISBL in compliance with its aims and objectives remembers all Irish and the Irish Diaspora in all armies who died in all wars and conflicts. IEAI in particular remembers the 50,000 Irish who died and estimated 500,000 members of the Irish Diaspora in all Armies who participated during the liberation of Belgium in the first and second world wars.

Everyone Welcome to attend.


This Irish in Europe WW1  commemoration aims to give greater insight to those 200,000 Irish born Volunteer (not conscripted) Soldiers who survived the trenches in Flanders Fields but at a great price to themselves and to their families who did not realise the extent of the horrors of trench warfare and hand to hand combat that left lasting psychological scars if not severe disabilities and ill health that led to an early grave for some.

The sacrifices of the survivors and their quest to stand up for the rights of small nations such as Belgium were never fully recognised during their lifetimes.

Let those who come after us see to it that their names be not forgotten
Hence it will have its fourth Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday in Brussels on Saturday 8 November at 11.30 am.


The IEAI will lay a wreath at the Anglo-Belgian War Memorial at Place Poelaert / Poelaertplein in front of Palais de Justice de Bruxelles and across from the Infantry Memorial of Brussels in memory of the Belgian foot soldiers who fought in World War I and II. (Metro or Tram Louise 3 minutes walk- It is embedded in wall on the right of the tramline direction Sablon and after Cercle de Lorraine ).


The Anglo-Belgian War Memorial commemorates the heroic Belgian people who helped the Irish and British prisoners of war during World War I. Designed by the British sculptor Charles Sargeant Jagger [masked]), the monument was inaugurated in 1923. The composition, in Brainvilliers stone, features figures of Irish, British and Belgian soldiers. The sides are covered with reliefs representing scenes of Belgian common folk tending to wounded British soldiers. There is also a relief of an Irish harp. A plaster cast of the statues of soldiers can be seen at the Military Museum in Brussels. The monument has just been restored and looks very much refreshed. 


Following the laying of the wreath, a poem by Irish Poet Francis Ledwidge will be recited. He enlisted in the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers in 1914 and was killed in the battle of Ypres on the 31st July 1917. See www.francisledwidge.com . After the ceremony, guests shall proceed to Pub-Mini Louise  for warm refreshments at Rue Jourdan  3(opposite Boss Window Displays) Brussels 1060 located to the right of Avenue Louise about 7 minutes walk from the memorial. On the way the group shall stop at the site of the former residence in exile of William Smith O Brien, one of the leaders of the Irish Rebellion of 1848 and direct descendent of King Brian Boru who was killed at the Battle of Clontarf in 1014. He also lived in Hungary where he advised the Hungarian Independence Movement. Every one is welcome to come along to the third annual Irish in Europe Remembrance Saturday ceremony.
“Your Donation to help defray costs would be much appreciated“
